FORM No. I.A. 506

Voucher No. 640

Date: August 15, 1938
Sir:

There is need of a larger cabinet in the Millbrook Indian Day School to protect the library and other books that are ever increasing.

The teacher assures me he will have a cabinet constructed by manual training boys if we can give him material. The cost will not be more than $10.00 for boards, glass, hinges, etc. I would recommend his request be granted.

Further, while it might be early, yet I would draw your attention to the fact that next year we will need more school accommodation. At present there are 27 pupils in the building, rather too crowded; and next year by a casual observation, I figure six or more will be added.

I went over the situation and concluded our present building could be extended back 12 feet, and a cellar for wood put underneath. This is only a layman's idea, but perhaps if one of the architects or builders of the Indian Affairs Branch is in the near vicinity he could visit here and give a better idea of what can be done. Or, if approved, a local builder might be asked to look over the situation and report back to your office.

Your obedient servant,

B. B. Fox,
Indian Agent,
Truro, N. S.

T. R. L. MacInnis,
Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.
EX'D.

Ottawa,
September 22, 1938.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 15th instant you may expend an amount not exceeding $10.00 in purchasing the material required to build a book case.

I note your statement that the school is becoming overcrowded. We are receiving so many demands for school accommodation in places where no schools are located at the present time that I doubt if it will be possible to provide funds in our appropriation for the year 1939-40 in order to enlarge the Millbrook School.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

B. B. Fox, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Truro, N. S.
Sir:

Your letter No. 47-1-5, dated Sept. 22, 1938 received and the second paragraph in reference to enlarging the Millbrook School noted.

While I regret that there is doubt funds will be possible in the appropriation for the year 1939-40 for the suggested work, after conference with the teacher, Mr. MacKinnon, I believe we have found a solution to our problem, if it is approved by the Department.

The younger children coming to school are void or lacking in English speaking and not only has the teacher to educate them in the regular way, but in many cases really has to teach the child to talk and understand English.

This takes so much of his time that it deprives the higher grades of the attention that they really require. Our suggestion is that the morning session, perhaps extended for a half or an extra hour be wholly given to the lower classes and the afternoon be wholly given to the higher grades. Mr. McKinnon, is willing to give the extra hours each day and I would recommend that an increase in salary to meet the extra hours would greatly encourage him to carry on the excellent work he is doing in our school.

His method of teaching is of the most up-to-date in the Province and marked improvement is shown among the children of the Millbrook Reservation.

Your obedient servant,

T. R. L. MacInnis,
Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.

E. H. Fox,
Indian Agent,
Truro, N. S.
Ottawa,
September 30, 1938.

EX'D.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 27th instant with further reference to the Millbrook Indian Day School. I have carefully considered the suggestion contained in your letter but I am inclined to feel that some difficulties would probably occur and consequently I do not feel able to favourably consider your suggestion.

In your letter of the 15th instant you stated that an extension could be made to the building and that a cellar could be placed under this extension. Please let me have an estimate of the probable cost of carrying out the work that you suggest. This information should be furnished at the earliest possible date in order that we can consider providing it in the appropriation for the next fiscal year.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

B. B. Fox, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Truro, N. S.
Oct. 31, 1938.

Date: [Blank]

Total: $13.05
Truro, N. S.
November 15, 1938.

Sir:

Following advice received in a recent letter from you re my petition for addition to our school, I beg to say that I got Gordon Hayman, a local contractor, to go over the matter and he gave me an estimate.

For an addition of 20 feet to the present building full width, which is 22 feet; and a cellar approximately eight feet deep, together with proper drainage and including a furnace, properly installed, at a total of $1350.

If he gets the contract, he assures me he will employ Indian labor wherever possible.

At present you will note the average attendance at the school is 27 daily, with an enrollment of 30, nearly double that when I first took over the Agency here.

This is too crowded even now and next year several more children will be ready to attend, with none of the present scholars to stop.

For the building such as the proposed enlarged one, the present heating system will not be sufficient, and the cheaper method besides a more healthy and sanitary one would be a furnace.

However, if it should meet the approval of the Department, I believe I could do the job much cheaper than the figure submitted. That is, I would undertake to supervise the alterations, with Indian labor all through, at only the cost of mileage for the trips it would be necessary to make. As I have to make a living otherwise than by the salary I receive, I could not stay on the building job continuously, unless additional remuneration was allowed.

This figure submitted by Mr. Hayman is only a basis for you to consider having money placed in the estimates for the next fiscal year.

Trusting this information meets your requirements and sincerely hoping the money may be found available to continue our special attention to education of the young, I am

Your obedient servant,

T. R. L. MacInnis,
Secretary,

Indian Agent.
Ottawa,
November 24, 1938.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 15th instant in connection with erecting an addition to the Millbrook Indian Day School.

I am not certain that it will be possible to provide funds next year but every endeavour will be made to do so. You should write to me again about June 1, 1939 and it will be decided at that time if the necessary funds can be provided.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Sir:

Some time ago on authority from the Indian Affairs Branch, I started milk to the pupils of our school as per instructions, followed later with an egg a day to certain of the children as directed in the subsequent authority from the Department.

At the beginning of supplying milk with Dr. Kent and a V. C. Nurse, we had the children weighed. After two months with the milk, eggs, and cod liver oil, today the Teacher, Mr. MacKinnon again weighed the children. The result showing is so satisfactory that even some of the Medical men with whom I conversed tonight marvelled.

I am happy to submit the weights taken by Dr. Kent and the nurse and the weight taken today of each of the children. I wish, however, to point out that with Dick and Martin Silliboy, they had much more clothing on today than at the time they were weighed by Dr. Kent. Also to make special note of Mary Marshall, who evidently has not made any gain. I am going to take her case up with Dr. Kent tomorrow to see if there is not something to be done for this child which gives every evidence of being in very poor health.

The report is as follows on separate sheet.

Your obedient servant,

T. R. L. MacInnis,
Secretary,

Dear Sir:

The Department is returning your voucher No. 730 unpaid. As you are aware Edward Paul is employed as school janitor of the Millbrook school at a salary of $50.00 a year. Under these circumstances we cannot understand why Emily Paul was employed.

You may submit another account covering the cost of the broom, soap, scrub brush and bon ami.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

B. B. Fox, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Truro, N. S.
Ottawa, January 1st, 1939.

The Honourable T. A. Crerar, M.P.,
Minister of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.

Dear Mr. Crerar:

Re: Indian Affairs.

I wish to bring to your attention the situation with respect to the Indian day schools in my constituency.

On the Millbrook reserve the accommodation is most inadequate for the number of children and there are at the present time five or six who are unable to attend school for this reason.

The situation at Shubenacadie is even worse. At that point there are some twenty children of school age and no school facilities. However, the building still stands, but no teacher has been employed for a number of years.

If it is the policy of the Department to give the Indian children some education the Millbrook school be enlarged and that at Shubenacadie repaired and a teacher employed.

Will you please favour me with your advice in the matter.

Yours sincerely,

G. T. Purdy
Sir:

Your letter No. 47-1-5, dated January 20, 1939 received and noted. In explanation I beg to say that a general scrubbing and cleaning of the school twice a year has been the order for several years. This is done during the summer and Christmas vacations.

On other occasions the work was done by a woman as in this instance, and a relief order given. However, material for the last cleaning was obtained from our regular grocer instead of a hardware store as formerly and I asked him to make separate accounts for the school. When Emilie Paul came to me for a relief order in December I told her if she would give the school a thorough cleaning I would give her an order. She did so, and when I gave her the order I marked on the slip "for cleaning school." Mr. Brenton placed this order in the school account and I let it go through that way.

The janitor keeps the school clean daily, but I believe a thorough house cleaning twice a year is essential. Especially where we have the stove in the centre of the room and manual training all in the same room, dust covers the blackboards and walls during the sessions.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent,
Truro, N. S.

R. A. Hoey,

As we are nearing a new year, when probably the proposed alterations to our school will be considered I would like to recommend that included in the amount voted for school improvement you endeavor to have approximately $200 placed for boring a well and installing a pump.

On the Reservation here there is not one really sanitary well and our school water supply is obtained from a well on the adjoining property where among the family have been several deaths from Tuberculosis.

I consulted O. Johnson, artesian well borer residing in this locality and he advised me that we could strike a good flow of water on our school property at about seventy-five feet. This well in Mr. Johnson's opinion would supply sufficient water for a large number on the Reservation as well as give the school kiddies a pure water for drinking.

Memorandum

Mrs. Wardle:

Re: Drainage, Millbrook Indian Day School, Nova Scotia.

In reference to my memorandum of the 16th instant in regard to the above I quote the following report received from our engineer in amplification of his previous wire:

"I visited the school after getting in touch with the Agent, Mr. John McMillan.

"At the site work was under way on an extension 20'x22' at the rear of the present building. Basement excavation had been taken out, footings placed and forms for the concrete walls were being erected. Soil is a heavy, red, gumbo type of clay, and quite wet below the surface, there appearing to be many springs in the vicinity. Water had collected in the excavation so that footings were completely covered. Under the circumstances drainage of the basement is necessary, and I would recommend following the usual practice of laying farm tile around the outside of footings together with a carry off drain from the basement floor with catch-basin this drain to empty into the large drainage ditch through the Reserve, which would be at a lower enough level about 15 feet from the new basement to carry off the water. Excavation of a trench through the type of material encountered in the basement would be very slow and it is difficult to estimate a cost in this connection. However, basing costs on the work at the new basement, of which only a rough idea is available, the following estimate of cost has been prepared for the proposed installations:

| Item                        | Cost   |
|-----------------------------|--------|
| Excavation, 100 c.y. @ $1.00 | $100.00 |
| Backfill, 100 c.y. @ $.25    | $25.00  |
| 68 lin.ft. farm tile in place| $15.00  |
| 150 " sewer pipe in place    | $65.00  |
| Catch basin, concrete        | $25.00  |
| Contingencies               | $20.00  |

Total - $250.00

I would suggest that the Indian Affairs Branch be furnished with this data for their information.

Respectfully submitted,

J. M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA,
Ontario."
August 22nd, 1939.

Memorandum to:

Dr. H.W. McGill

Re Millbrook Indian Day School,
Colchester Indian Agency, N.S.

Referring to your memorandum of the 3rd instant, we understand that Mr. William A. Hingley, R.R. No. 3, Truro, N.S., has submitted an offer to complete the well at the price mentioned in your memorandum, namely $2.50 a foot.

If necessary it will therefore be satisfactory to engage him to do the work. His offer would, of course, include the necessary five inch casing.

In view of the proposed survey that is being made of the Indian Agencies in Nova Scotia, might it not be well to postpone incurring this expense until Mr. Arneil has personally examined into the situation? It may be that when the final decision is reached as to the general Indian administration in that Province the Indians at this Agency will be moved to some other location, in which event the well would be of no further value.

Chief Executive Assistant.

Indian Affairs Branch, OTTAWA.

In reply to yours of the 19th inst re my voucher # 2424 covering the cost of cleaning the school on the Millbrook Indian Reserve, please be advised that there was a change of janitors at that time. The resigning janitor left the school in rather poor condition and over the holidays I authorized a general cleaning up. The windows had to be done, a few panes of glass installed, the floor scrubbed, the boards cleaned etc., and I considered that it would be very unfair to the new janitor to insist that this be done for the usual salary. The other janitor had left the reserve temporarily. All this work was done for the allowance provided.

I feel that to expect a janitor to scrub a school of this size once a month or even once a quarter along with the usual labor of making kindling, fires, making the usual repairs around a school, etc for a fee of five dollars per month that you are getting one hundred cents out of every dollar. The school in question is approx. 20' x 44' which is a great deal of scrubbing. It is also heated by a furnace, not the usual small school stove. I have been expecting the janitors to keep order and trespassers away from school property, mow the grass occasionally, etc which involves a great deal of time and labor. To supplement the small fee I, occasionally, give the janitor a load of wood. Were it not for this there would be no janitors available for at least two of our day schools.

H. C. Rice,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 12th re Mrs. Brooks. She never advises me when she requires anything, but seems to run to you with all her troubles. I have about 125 cords of wood cut on what is known as the rifle range lot back of the Millbrook reserve. This was cut last year but on account of having no snow it was impossible to get it out. The first snow this winter I arranged to have a team start hauling it out and up until the snow failed us they were hauling steady and distributing same to the Indian families on relief. Mrs. Brooks received two loads of this wood, and from what I can understand her son Charlie stole quite a bit of this from her. Have been waiting for more snow so I could get the balance of this wood out. I am up against the same proposition on this reserve and short of wood because of unfavourable hauling conditions. Will try and get her a load from here to keep her going at the earliest possible date. The school was closed down for one day on account of water in the cellar, that was at the time of the big rain. This place has been ditched a good many times, but cannot seem to overcome it. To have it fixed properly it would incur quite an expense which the Indian Affairs Branch do not feel like spending on this school.

Trusting this is the information you require,

Yours very truly,

Dear Mr. Purdy:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of February 17th.

In July, 1939, an addition was erected on the Millbrook Indian Day School by Mr. Howard Hayman, Contractor of Truro, Nova Scotia. In the course of excavating for the addition it was found that a great deal of water collected in the hole thus made. On August 18, 1939, an engineer of our Surveys and Engineering Branch reported as follows:

"At the site, work was under way on an extension 20'x22' at the rear of the present building. Basement excavation had been taken out, footings placed and forms for the concrete walls were being erected. Soil is a heavy, red, gumbo type of clay, and quite wet below the surface, there appearing to be many springs in the vicinity. Water had collected in the excavation so that footings were completely covered. Under the circumstances drainage of the basement is necessary, and I would recommend following the usual practice of laying farm tile around the outside of footings together with a carry off drain from the basement floor with catch-basin, this drain to empty into the large drainage ditch through the Reserve, which would be at a low enough level about 150 feet from the new basement to carry off the water. Excavation of a trench through the type of material encountered in the basement would be heavy work and it is difficult to estimate a cost in this connection. However, basing costs on the work at
the new basement of which only a rough idea is available, the following estimate of cost has been prepared for the proposed installations:

- Excavation, 100 c.y. @ $1.00 = $100.00
- Backfill, 100 c.y. @ .25 = 25.00
- 88 lin. ft. farm tile in place = 15.00
- 150 lin. ft. sewer pipe in place = 65.00
- Catch basin, concrete = 25.00
- Contingencies = 20.00

Total: $250.00

In accordance with his recommendations, he was authorized to carry out the construction of the necessary ditch and the installation of the whole tile.

Since that time we have received no complaints concerning the flooding of the basement at this school. Therefore, it would seem that the water mentioned in your letter, is the result of the unusually heavy rains which we understand have occurred in that vicinity recently. This has evidently caused the above rise in both the ground water level and in the water flow from the many springs which our engineer reported in the vicinity of the school.

Yours sincerely,

W.J.F. Pratt,
Private Secretary.

Secretary of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

There is a matter of importance to me as teacher of the Millbrook School, Indian Reserve, which I kindly ask your attention. Since taking the school I have suffered many inconveniences in respect to boardinghouse. The location of the Reserve makes it impossible to obtain a suitable boarding house. Will you please grant me a Pass from here to my home at Collon, a distance of ten miles. By doing this you will greatly favour.

Yours respectfully,

Jessie Scott.
OTTAWA, 27th January, 1904

The Deputy Superintendent General:

Miss Jessie Scott, who has been teaching the Millbrook (N.S.) school for nearly three years writes stating that during all that time she has suffered many inconveniences on account of the difficulty in securing a suitable boarding place, and asks the Department to grant her a pass to her home which is ten miles from the Reserve. She evidently thinks that as the Intercolonial railway is a Government road there would be no difficulty in complying with her request. I do not see that the Department could very well ask for a pass but it is quite certain that it is next to impossible for a white teacher to find a decent place to board on an Indian reserve.

The only way I see to overcome the difficulty would be to add two rooms to the schoolhouse, which was only put up in '98 at a cost of $269.00. I would suggest that the Agent be asked to state the probable cost of this work.

I suppose a cheap rate commutation ticket could be obtained from the Railway but the teacher would naturally expect to have her present salary of $300.00 increased to meet its cost.

[Signature]
OTTAWA, 28th January, 1904

Sir,

The teacher of the Indian school on the Hillbrook reserve says that she has great difficulty in securing a suitable boarding place on the reserve. It is thought that this difficulty might be overcome if an addition were made to the schoolhouse, which would provide two rooms. The Department would like to have a report from you as to whether an addition could be made to the present building, and if so, what would be the probable cost entailed.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Thomas B. Smith, Esq.
Indian Agent,
Truro, N.S.
Received a letter from the Dept. of Indian Affairs dated Ottawa, Jan. 19th, wishing me to report, as to the probable cost of an addition of two rooms to the school house.

Two rooms added to the school house say about 12 feet square properly finished would cost in the neighborhood of $500— one hundred and fifty dollars. It would be necessary to have the building insured, which it is not at present. A two roomed cottage would cost from $250 to $300 more and not be so much risk on account of fire.

I asked Miss Scott the teacher what the matter was as she has a nice boarding place about 250 yards from the school house. There did not seem to be anything the matter except the board like an imaginary illness.

H. B. Smith
Indian Agent
Poveshell

Rev. Dear Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your favor of the 10th inst., in reference to the payment of Provincial Government grants to teachers in Indian Schools; and in reply, shall explain the situation as briefly as possible.

It appears there was question of employing a teacher for the Indian reservation at Sydney, and it was sought to secure for her the Provincial grant. In the course of correspondence the Superintendent wrote me, in part, as follows: (I only quote the most relevant points.)

"In McKinnon's inspectorate, it was found that provincial aid was given to a teacher in an Indian school who had a Provincial license. The Dominion Government Agent considered it strange, and so did I, from the other point of view. The only case in which I authorized the Provincial aid to be paid a teacher was when the school was taken under the charge of the trustees of the school section."

"Several members of parliament have been approached, asking the grant to be given if it is possible. Now, it is possible only on condition of the schools being assumed by some Board of Trustees of the public schools. If the Dominion Government can thus subsidize an Indian..."
school, I think the way is clear for us—possibly not. But there is no possibility of an giving a grant to a teacher not engaged in a free public school.

"What has been the practice in your Inspectorial district? And do you think an arrangement can be made to bring the Indian school under one of our school boards."

You will observe that the above possible concession presupposes an Indian school established in a public school section organized under our school system.

To this I replied that in my district, there were two Indian schools, one in each county. That when I assumed office, I found the practice had been to pay the provincial grant to the teachers in both, provided they were regularly licensed teachers; that I had followed the practice ever since, placing the names of the teachers in my paylists, and entering the Indian sections in the County Fund Sheets for purposes of statistics, but apportioning to them no share in the County Funds, and that such sheets had always been approved by the Education Department.

Next, I received a letter containing the following:

"You should inform anyone teaching in an Indian school that they need not expect any provincial grant from the Province of Nova Scotia unless they are regularly under a school board and are in every respect carrying out the Nova Scotia law as well as the Dominion laws. The Dominion authorities should be notified in the case you specify, and requested to make good the loss of the Provincial grant to the teacher."

OTTAWA, 27th October, 1903

The Deputy Superintendent General:

Mr Agent Fraser of St Peter's Nova Scotia forwards a letter from Mr Public School Inspector McNeil on the subject of Provincial aid to Indian schools.

The Nova Scotia Government has decided to withdraw the grant previously paid to qualified teachers employed by this Department on the ground that such schools do not comply with the requirements of the Nova Scotia School Law (Sec.68, page 19). Our Agent states that the teacher lately engaged by him to take charge of the Salmon River school was employed on the understanding that her salary would be supplemented by this grant and he asks the Department to use its influence with the Nova Scotia Government to have the grant continued, or provide the difference.

I do not see that this Department has any claim on the Government of Nova Scotia for a grant towards the salary of its teachers, and as it will not continue payment without compliance with its School Law, which is impossible, the only thing to be done is to increase the salaries if qualified teachers cannot be found for the amount now paid by the Department, and I would suggest that an all-round rate of $300.00 be paid in Nova Scotia.
If there are any reserves near enough to white schools for the children to attend, it would be well to try and arrange with the trustees for their tuition; in which event the Indian school could be closed and the Provincial grant to the teacher supplemented by a tuition fee for each child in attendance.

OTTAWA, 29th October, 1903

The Deputy Superintendent General:

In further reference to the question of Provincial aid to Indian schools in Nova Scotia I beg to say that for the following reasons, the teachers of such schools are not entitled, under the Education Act of Nova Scotia, to receive any amount provided in Section 68 of the above Act:

The Indian schools in this Province are situated on Indian reserves which are exempt from all taxation. By the British North America Act, Indians and lands reserved for Indians are dealt with by the Dominion Government and not by the Provincial Government, which has power to make legislation respecting education, and the Indians are exempt from the provisions of the Education Act as wards of the Government.

A teacher in Nova Scotia, who wishes to draw the aid provided by the Provincial Treasury, must first be legally qualified and the school must be conducted according to the Provincial Law, which provides that each school shall be under the control of a Board of Trustees who are elected by the rate-payers. As there are no rate-payers on the reserve, a Board of Trustees cannot be elected according to this Act. Teachers of Indian schools on reserves are therefore ineligible for Provincial aid.

Sir,

With reference to your letter of the 19th ultimo, I beg to say that on a recent visit to the Salmon River Reserve, I took occasion to carefully examine the school conducted by Miss Henriette O'Toole, Indian Teacher, both with regard to class work and to the condition of the buildings, grounds, fences, etc., and, as a result of my inspection, I have to submit the following report:

I requested Miss O'Toole, who is a normal School graduate, to give lessons and exercises to the five classes that were present at the time, which she did with alacrity; and her method of teaching showed proficiency of a high order. In my estimation her capability as a teacher of her class cannot be questioned; and her all-round qualifications which she uses in the performance of her duties to the best advantage, under the circumstances, as demonstrated to me, entitle her to an increase of salary, which I respectfully recommend.

She had unwittingly the Department's idea of teaching Indian girls attending school to sew and to make simple articles of clothing. Having already given them sewing to her school instructions in useful needlework, at which she is an expert. She informed me that her pupils showed particular aptitude and much interest in acquiring knowledge of that kind, and that she would be much pleased to continue such instructions on a more extended scale. She also expressed her willingness to conduct a garden in connection with her school, providing suitable ground can be obtained.

It is to be regretted that Miss O'Toole's efforts as a teacher have been paralyzed to a serious extent for
want of proper accommodations, the school-room itself under present circumstances being very uncomfortable, and I shall endeavour to show. It is supposed to occupy the whole building whose dimensions are 16' x 24', and in the past or walls but part of it is used as a store-room for fuel, the wood shed having been yet provided. Besides, there is no porch or entry to the house, and every time the only door is opened the occupants of the school get the benefit, to a certain extent, of weather conditions outside.

Accepting a fair supply of books, slates, maps, etc., the school-room is practically void of suitable furniture. The seats are long benches 22 inches high, made roughly of deal planks, and they extend from side wall to within eighteen inches of the centre of the room, leaving but one alley or passage, 3 feet wide between the door and the teacher's platform. The desks correspond in length with the seats and are made of deals and inch boards. They are 2 ft. 9 inches high at the back and 5 inches lower in front, with a flat top 3 inches wide and a slant face one foot wide.

The arrangement of seats and desks in two rows, beginning near the front or entrance of the school-room and stopping close to the teacher's platform, is the only one possible with such seats and desks, and is a source of constant annoyance to a pupil anxious to take or leave his seat without disturbing all the others occupying the same bench. Therefore, condemn these seats and desks as unsuitable in every particular—dimensions, form, and arrangement—and strongly advise replacing them with new desks of proper dimensions, and of modern pattern.

The teacher's desk is a common board table.
three feet square and should be discarded for something more appropriate. The book case, or cupboard, is simply a small box fastened to the wall and hardly serves the purpose intended.

The interior of the school house has never been finished, the walls having received but one rough coat of plaster. The floor is defective, allowing the cold air from beneath to come through, and increasing the difficulty of keeping the school-room warm and comfortable. These conditions require to be improved. Stone windows also should be provided.

In my judgment the area of school grounds at Salmon River does not exceed one fourth of an acre, and it is not fenced. In fact, no fence is necessary unless the grounds can be enlarged by the acquisition of other land. Suitable ground for a garden adjoins the school premises, but whether the owners will dispose of it or not I have been unable, so far, to ascertain.

Now, having run over our duties, I think that a porch or entry to the school house, and a wind-shed, should be provided as soon as possible. Other improvements could not well be undertaken till the spring.

In connection with the school, there are two good aboats, in good condition.

Your obedient servant,

J. Boyd,
Indian Agent.

In December, last, Miss Henrietta O'Toole, teacher of the Salmon River School, sent in her resignation, which was forwarded to the Department by Mr. Boyd, Indian Superintendent, who recommended the appointment of Miss Charlotte Mary Devereaux in her stead. Mr. Agent McDonald also endorsed Miss Devereaux's appointment and there is a letter on file from Mr. Gillis, Barrister, of Sydney, Cape Breton, addressed to Miss O'Toole in which he states that he will be very glad to do what he can to secure Miss Devereaux the position, provided she has the requisite qualifications. Miss Devereaux is the holder of a Second-class certificate, which was forwarded to the Department and approved, and she was appointed at a salary of $350.00 per annum.

On the 26th ultimo Mr. Gillis sent the following wire to the Department:- "Present teacher Indian School St. Peters not satisfactory and must not be re-engaged. I recommend the engagement of Mr. Ernest McNeil Barra Head near St. Peters as teacher of this school. Please see that

The Department has had no official complaints

Department would be justified in summarily dismissing her without notice, especially at this time of the year when it would be a difficult matter for a teacher to obtain another school. It is for the Department to say what action is to be taken on Mr. Gillis' telegram.

Since the foregoing was written a letter has been received from Mr. Gillies in which he again insists upon the dismissal of Miss Devereaux, as he says for good and sufficient reasons. Case of Miss Devereux.

There would not appear to be any national union of teachers to defend the profession; but the case of the dismissal of Miss Charlotte Devereux—referred to in this column yesterday under the heading, "Woman's Place in Politics"—is strong evidence in proof of the need of some such organization. Charges are made respecting the competence of the teacher by the Rev. R. L. Macdonald, Indian Agent at St. Peters, and serious reflection is cast upon the ability of women as teachers by the Rev. Father, who offers the opinion of "the true educationist." The charges were made by the Indian agent in a report at the request of the government. No inquiry was held as to the foundation of the charges against Miss Devereux; she was dismissed from her position as teacher at the Salmon River school on the report made by the Indian agent. The statistics of the department show that the attendance during the last four years, under the teaching of women is quite equal to that of any other period in the school's history. The public school inspector for the county sent a protest to the department of Indian Affairs in which he states: "I have just been informed that the teacher of the Salmon River school, this county, Miss Devereux, has been dismissed by the Indian agent, a man having neither license, experience, nor professional training, whereas the deceased teacher is an experienced and competent Normal School Diploma—a young lady of irreproachable character—in every respect. I believe that this does not count an ordinary fact, therefore, I feel it too much to ask the reason for this change in the management of the school. Because if it is as commonly reported, I would like to say that I am very much afraid to have nothing to do with those schools if they are to be controlled by political influence. The schools in this county are not managed on those principles."

Other documents, including statutory declarations, and the annual report of the department of Indian Affairs, were produced in defense of Miss Devereux; but as the Rev. Father, Indian Agent, might say, in his opinion of the true educationist, "she held no warrant," where departmental judgment was concerned. Mr. Scott, the Superintendent of Indian Education, states in his report of the Salmon River school:

"Miss O'Toole, who conducted this school successfully for a number of years, has been dismissed this past year and Miss Devereux was appointed as her successor. Miss Devereux has the normal school second class certificate and is meeting with success in her work. She also teaches sewing to the girls."

The former teacher deposited a statutory declaration in defense and support of Miss Devereux; also a very important report by Mr. A. J. Boyd, the Superintendent of Indian Agencies for the Maritime Provinces, included along with the report of Mr. Scott, in the annual report of the department of Indian Affairs. After referring to the fact that employment in most of the occupations in this country today is more remunerative than teaching, and drawing the inference that the department will soon be unable to advance its "minimum wage" for teachers if it wishes to continue in its employ those worth retaining or to engage others whose services are worth having, Mr. Boyd states:

"Experience forces me to the conclusion that females succeed better than males as Indian teachers. At any rate there can be no doubt that the schools at Truro, Sydney, Bear River, and the school at Glasgow, which have always been conducted by women, and by ladies are distinctly ahead in the matter of education, of those that have always been conducted by men and the most backward of the Indian schools are those conducted by means of a male teacher. The standing of the best school in the Maritime schools taught by Mrs. Annie McNeil and Miss Charlotte M. Devereux represents the highest degree of the best school taught by a male teacher; so that there seems to be very much in favor of the ladies as teachers. The preponderance in that respect has impressed me from the beginning of my experience with Indian education. There is still filling vacancies that will be done away from time to time on the department's staff of teachers in Nova Scotia, and I urge the selection of ladies who possess the necessary qualifications.

The statutory declarations of two women teachers regarding the faithful carrying out of instructions, the departmental records regarding attendance, and the report of the deputy minister of the department that the department has no intention of dispensing with your services as teacher of the Salmon River Indian school so long as you are satisfactory," is the protest of the Inspector of Schools for the county, the testimony of the Superintendent of Indian Education, and the high commendation of the Superintendent of Indian Agencies for the Maritime Provinces are all selected in favor of a report full of village gossip by a clerical gentleman—and without inquiry into the report—by the government. A qualified woman teacher with a normal school diploma has been discharged, and an inexperienced person possessing neither license nor professional training has been appointed to the position. It is a matter of grave affecting the teaching profession. It also reveals the existence and curse of political patronage.

THE COST OF LIVING—REPORT OF DEPARTMENT OF LABOUR.

Hon. T. W. CROTHERS (Minister of Labour): Mr. Speaker, before the Orders of the Day are called, I would like to table a special report just issued by my department, which seems to be particularly opportune at the present time. Its subject is the important one of the rise in the cost of living, in which everyone is interested and naturally so in view of recent developments. This is not the first report on the subject to be published by the department. A report issued in 1910 gave a review of the course of prices in Canada from 1890 up to the previous year. Since then annual reports have been issued bringing the statistics up to date, the first covering the year 1910, and the second the year 1911. The present report covers the year 1912. I think I may say that it is a much better document than any of its predecessors. During the past year I have very materially strengthened the statistical branch of my department, which is in charge of Mr. Coates; and the result has been a marked increase in the efficiency of its work, as will be seen by comparing the report with its predecessors.

It is a comprehensive field, I may add, that it is only the precursor of a considerable increase in statistics which the department is mapped out.

The report gives a detailed review of the movement of wages, salaries, and retail prices in Canada during the past year. Altogether, nearly three hundred articles, selected on account of their representative character, have been covered. The movement as a whole has been analyzed from various points of view. For each article a considerable mass of information has been assembled, covering such points as production, demand, trade conditions, &c., &c., and indicating the actual prices and the causes of the recent advance. Grains, live stock, meats, dairy products, fish, groceries, textiles, leather, lumber, fuel, house-furnishings, and chemicals are only some of the classes of articles discussed. The retail prices given in the report are collected from every locality in Canada having over 10,000 inhabitants. There is an appendix to the report which treats of a similar movement in Great Britain, the United States and Australasia, and another appendix in which statistics and other matters indicative of the general condition on prices have been brought together.

I might say that the general result of the inquiry shows that prices went up by probably over six per cent. in 1912.

For the first six months the advance was due chiefly to short world supply of food-stuffs on the back of which came a severe winter. There was a recession from this in the summer due to the crop prospects that proved fair, but in the autumn the rise set in again, being due this time to increases in materials rather than foods, and being indicative of the widespread prosperity of industry which prevailed not only in this country but in Great Britain and the United States.

Hon. members may have noticed in the press recently that the question of the cost of living has been actively debated in the Ontario legislature, and that the opinion was expressed that the subject was one that could be more effectively handled by the Federal Government. My own personal view is that the problem is one that is world-wide in its extent, and that what is really required is an investi-

Work of the Commission of Conservation in 1912.

A review of the work of the Commission of Conservation must necessarily be a fragmentary statement; its functions are wholly investigatory and advisory. It does not appear to be necessary to mention the services of our inspectors to protect men engaged in mining operations, nor the services of our engineers to carry out public health regulations, nor the services of our inspectors to grade grain, nor officials to administer fishing regulations, nor the care and supervision of methods of protecting the forests, methods of preventing loss of fish in the lakes, methods of preserving and preventing the spread and dissemination of dangerous pests, methods of controlling water-powers, and methods of increasing the yield of the fisheries. All these matters are, at the same time, conserving the fertility of the soil.

Mr. KYTE:

If the commission undertook administrative work, it would be impossible for any administrator to stand aloof and occupy the position of impartial critic, it would be impossible for any administrator to subject without being hampered by any administrative acts of its own or of any allied body.

To get a comprehensive view of the work of the commission, it is necessary to review the work that is being carried on under the various divisions.

Committee on Lands.

The agricultural survey was continued throughout Canada on thirteen counties in order to secure an accurate diagnosis of agricultural conditions. The results of these surveys will be published during the present year.

Committee on Fisheries.

In Peterborough and Hastings counties an investigation of forest conditions has been carried on under the direction of Dr. B. E. Fenton. This work has been conducted on a large area of cut-over territory, and the results indicate that there is a great extent of reforestation which is possible, and to what extent reforestation of such territory can be profitably put.

The report of a forest survey of Nova Scotia conducted under the direction of Dr. Fenton, at the expense of the province, has been published.

An investigation of forest revenue and taxation was carried on in British Columbia to determine what extent existing methods of taxation are sufficient to provide adequate private owners. Taxation in the United States has been investigated for comparison, but no attempt has hitherto been made to ascertain its effect in Canada.

Committee on Mines.

The investigation conducted last year in the province of western Canada, to ascertain the possibilities of the utilization of by-products and the safety of the mines, was extended this year to the coal mines of eastern Canada. Mr. Duff, who has been engaged in this work, visited all the principal coal mines, coal-burning plants, and coal-burning plants in New Brunswick during past summer. The results of these investigations are now being embodied in a report which will be available for publication early in 1913.

A report on the mining industry in Canada has been printed. Until recently, whether the establishment of mine rescue stations. The report was based upon the experience gained in organizing this work. REPORT OF INSPECTOR M.J.T. MACNEIL ON THE SALMON RIVER DAY SCHOOL.

In order to overtake this school before the closing for the Christmas holidays and make the semi-annual inspection required of me before the end of the calendar year, I made a special trip down there, fifteen miles, arriving at 9.15 A.M., to be informed that there would be no school that day, because the school room was to be prepared for a Christmas celebration. And this on Thursday. This was done by order of the Indians, themselves, without previously consulting or notifying the teacher, who had, therefore, no responsibility in the matter. The teacher was present at the school house but the scholars had been notified that they need not attend that day or next except at the celebration. I stayed till 10.10 taking notes and working as above stated with some preaching, when, no scholars appearing I took my departure. I would suggest that the school should not be closed at any time without the teacher receiving notice in advance so that he, in his turn, could notify the Inspector and prevent possible disappointments.

We have a regulation requiring all teachers to notify the Inspector on the opening of school and also when for any reason the school is to be closed for any period. This rule should be imposed on the teachers of Indian schools, as well.

I hereby tender my resignation as teacher of the Salmon River Indian School. I write in the hope that the war, in which we are at present engaged, is so prolonged that my services can be better utilized in some other work, military or agricultural. Dear Sir:

On the 15th instant I posted to you reports on the Indian schools at Salmon River Reserve, Richmond County, and Big Harbor Island, Inverness County, with my accounts for the same. I would ask you to kindly send me a few blank forms for such reports.

In these reports we are asked to make such suggestions on existing conditions as we deem proper. I ventured to make, in one of my reports, a suggestion on the matter of the salaries of the teachers in these schools. I should like to amplify the remarks referred to by a few further observations, which space in the report did not permit.

One of these teachers gives her salary as $500, with an expected bonus of $150. The other gives hers as $750. I presume it is the same in both cases. This, boiled down, comes to $2.50 per month, or $2.08 per day.

Compare this with almost any other calling. An office girl, living under comfortable conditions, commands anywhere from $65 to $150 per month. A common sailor gets $50 and upwards, with board. An ordinary charwoman gets $2.00 and upwards, with two or three meals per day. These teachers have to exist on $2.08 per day and "find themselves"!

Then look at the living conditions. Boarding in an Indian house on the reserve being out of the question, they have to live at an inconvenient distance from the school while they have to reach as best they can in all weather, and in winter time by well nigh impassable roads.

The school house at Big Harbor Island has living rooms for the teacher. A girl cannot be expected to live there alone, miles away from white people and surrounded by half civilized Indians.

I understand that the teacher at Big Harbor Island contemplates staying at the school house at least a part of the winter, in which case she will require a companion to stay with her. This, of course, is a personal matter, but
I think it is worthy of consideration. It seems to me that the resources of the Indian Department are not so cramped that it cannot treat its employees with fairness, if not with liberality and generosity, and I respectfully submit these remarks to those in authority, trusting they will receive favorable consideration.

I am,

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Inspector of Schools

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of December 30th,

No. 60-1-1. I notice that, naturally enough, you base your estimate of teachers in Nova Scotia on the lists published in the Journal of Education. You overlook the fact that these are minimum prescriptions, lower than which teachers are not permitted to accept, and the further fact that these salaries, provided by the school sections, are supplemented by the Provincial Aid paid to the teachers direct by the Governments.

Even then, I am free to admit that the salaries of your Indian teachers compare favorably with those of many of our lower classed teachers. If this Province could secure its rights in the matter of the Western school lands, it would not be robbed of its best teachers, as well as of the means of paying them. But what I wish to emphasize is the conditions under which the teachers in the Indian schools have to live and to work. I never visit their schools without experiencing a feeling of sympathy, if not of pity, for them. I have two daughters engaged in teaching, and I would not have one of them employed in these schools for three times what they are receiving, and their salaries run well into four figures.

I have no personal interest to serve in this connection. I have probably visited these and the other schools for the last time, but I should be glad, before retiring, to do something to better the condition of persons whom I consider very inadequately paid. If good teachers are to be secured for these schools, and held, when they are, the remuneration will have to be more attractive.

I am,

Yours very truly,

Sir:

I have your letter of the 23rd instant, with reference to the attendance at the Salmon River Indian Day School and the services that are being performed by the truant officer, Andrew Alex. In reply I beg to say it is noted that as Andrew Alex is an old man, he has not been attending to his duties, and his services should, therefore, be dispensed with.

The Department will approve of the appointment of Tom Marshall, the present constable for the Reserve, to take up duties as truant officer for this Reserve from the 1st of September, next, the date on which the school will reopen after the summer holidays. It is expected that he will attend to the duties as truant officer faithfully and see that all Indian children of school age, who are in good health, attend school regularly each day it is open. The teacher should furnish a report to the truant officer each day regarding the absentee pupils, and he should then visit the homes and endeavour to have them brought to school. It is thought that if a strong effort is taken by the truant officer there will be a marked improvement in the attendance. The salary allowed Marshall for his services will be at the same rate as was previously paid.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

Although Miss Gibson has taught at the school for two years she only has a Grade IX certificate, with no Normal training, no other teaching experience and no License to teach from the Council of Public Instruction. Her work as a teacher has not been satisfactory. When I spoke to the Provincial School Inspector for the district concerning her ability as a teacher, he stated that she would not be allowed to teach in any of the white schools. If that is the case, then I do not think it reasonable that she should be a satisfactory teacher for an Indian school.

In reference to Miss Tina MacDonald's qualifications, I beg to say that she has a "B" certificate and fifteen years experience as a teacher. Mr. Benoit, local school inspector, states as follows: "I wish to say that Miss MacDonald is not musical, and I do not know her qualifications from the artistic standpoint; but in all other respects I feel satisfied she would be eminently satisfactory."

It would appear then that Miss Gibson's services should be discontinued in view of the foregoing facts and a new teacher appointed for this school.

As Miss Tina MacDonald's qualifications are satisfactory to the local school inspector, I would therefore recommend her appointment as teacher at the Salmon River Indian Day School, her duties to commence about September 1st, next.
With the school season approaching, I should be pleased to have your ruling in this matter as soon as possible.

I wish to say, in connection with this matter, that I have waiting to receive Miss Gibson's resignation before taking action in this case; but now I feel that steps must be taken at once in order to have a new teacher for next term.

Memorandum:

MR. BUSKARD.

With reference to the inquiry of the Honourable Mr. Rhodes, I may say that teachers of Indian day schools are considered temporary employees and are engaged from year to year. The usual practice is to request the church interested in any particular school to nominate the workers. Appointments are then confirmed by the Department.

With particular reference to the Salmon River Indian Day School, near St. Peters, N.S., I may say that no church takes an active interest in the management and therefore the appointment of a teacher rests with the Department of Indian Affairs. The present incumbent is Miss Tina MacDonald, who was favourably recommended in Mr. Lamb's letter to me of September 18th, last. Miss MacDonald's services have been satisfactory. The Department expects that she will ask to be continued in our employ during the next academic year.

Ottawa, Sept. 20, 1934.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your telegram of the 14th instant, advising the Department that you have received the resignation of Miss Tena Macdonald, teacher of the Salmon River Indian Day School.

To succeed Miss Macdonald, the appointment of Miss Frances Madden, of Point Michaud, is approved, at the same salary as allowed the former teacher, viz.: $70 a teaching month.

Please inform Miss Madden of her appointment and arrange for her to take charge of the school.

You should advise the Department, as soon as possible, regarding the exact date on which Miss Macdonald discontinued duties and also the date on which Miss Madden takes charge. This information is required in order that the correct amount of salary may be paid to each of them.

Your obedient servant,

March 8, 1926
Extract from Report of Inspector d'Entremont on the Salmon River Indian Day School - dated June 1st, 1926.

School room needs repairing, viz. windows, desks and cupboard. Also painting is needed all over.

Wood shed is O.K. and water closet also, all belonging to Indian department.

The school and equipment does not compare with those of Malagawatch and Whycocomagh. It has been neglected, and very much so.

As you may not know we are having a backward spring, cold and damp weather. No fire at school since the last two weeks for the janitor is away after pulp wood. It was far from being comfortable this morning.
Ottawa, June 7th, 1926.

Sir:

The Public School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Salmon River Indian Day School, states that the schoolroom needs repairing, and that the windows, desks and cupboard, also the interior, should be painted. He also states that this school and the equipment do not compare with our other Indian schools in Cape Breton which he has visited, and that this building and equipment have been neglected and very much so. He further states that, as the janitor had been away, there was no fire for two weeks previous to his visit and the school was far from comfortable.

I have to request that you will forward a report regarding the repairs and painting required, giving an estimate of the cost of any work which you would recommend be carried out.

You should also enquire as to whether the janitor has been attending to his duties, as there does not appear to be any reason why the children should suffer from want of heat. If the janitor was absent, it is thought that the teacher could have arranged to have the older boys light the fires and see that sufficient heat was provided.

Your early report on the above matters will oblige,

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

L. A. Boudreau, Esq.,

Ottawa, Sept. 13, 1926.

Sir:

Miss MacDonald, travelling nurse for this Department for the province of Nova Scotia, has strongly recommended that a hot midday lunch be supplied the pupils of the Salmon River Indian Day School each school day. She states that such meal should consist of hot soup or broth with biscuits, milk, cheese, sugar and cocoa. She also says that the actual preparation of the lunch in the school would serve a very useful educational lesson; that it would be of great benefit to the health of the children and encourage a more regular attendance.

Please discuss this matter with the teacher and ascertain whether she, with the assistance of the older girl pupils, could prepare this hot lunch and arrange for the serving of same. If arrangements can be made for its serving, it will be necessary to furnish the appliances and you may purchase a number of enamel cups, one kettle, one large saucepan, a dishpan and a small quantity of dish towelling as well as sufficient biscuits, cheese, cocoa, sugar and condensed milk sufficient for the serving of the meal. The Department will rely on you to see that no unnecessary expense is incurred in the purchase of the supplies. We will expect to hear from you, stating whether you have been able to arrange with the teacher for the serving of this hot lunch.

Properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, should be forwarded covering the expenditure incurred in the purchase of the supplies. This lunch is to be served to the pupils during the fall and winter months only, from October first to the middle of April, next.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Ottawa, July 8th, 1927.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 4th instant, relative to the repairs, painting, etc., required at the Salmon River Indian Day School building.

In reply I beg to say that you may arrange to have this work completed during the present summer holidays. We understand the following is required:

- Re-shingling of roof,
- Installing of new door with Yale lock,
- Painting interior of school building and repairing outhouses.

You should arrange for the purchase of all material required after obtaining competitive prices, and you should make the purchase from the firm quoting the lowest price. You should also arrange for the labour in having the work carried out. This work should be under the charge of a competent foreman, and should be inspected by you from time to time in order to see that it is being carried out in a satisfactory manner. The total cost should not exceed your estimate of approximately $300, and it is expected that you will endeavour to have this work carried out at less expense if you can do so.

When the work is completed, you should forward certified accounts, in duplicate, covering the cost of the material, together with a memorandum attached showing the names of the firms asked to quote and the prices quoted, and labour returns, in duplicate, for the labour employed. A supply of forms for the purpose is enclosed herewith. Should you require an advance to pay for labour, the same will be sent you upon request.

The question of these repairs should receive your early attention in order that they can be completed before the school reopens after the summer holidays.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Inspector
Sir:-

I beg to report that I have recently inspected the Indian Day School at Chapel Island Reserve and wish to advise you that conditions there could be much better than they are. The school building itself is in a fair state of repair although being a little on the small side. There should be three new desks installed to take care of a full attendance properly. The teacher also should have a new desk. There should be a new heater installed. The present one is a wood stove and it is badly in need of repairs. The great fault to be found with stoves of that type is that students sitting near the stove are too warm while those sitting in a more remote part of the room do not get an equal amount of heat.

I would suggest that a new heater of the "air circulator" type be installed in this school. Other things that are required for the school are: 2 dozen drinking cups, 2 wash basins, 6 towels and one water pail.

The attendance here is fair. In the past there has been a great amount of loitering about the premises by the young people at night. This practice, on several occasions, has been the cause of much damage being done here. Strict orders have been issued to all the Indians of that reserve that the school grounds are out of bounds to all during the hours that the school is not in session and the teacher has been instructed to report any further complaints of this kind. Thus we hope to improve conditions eventually. I trust that you will see fit to authorize the above recommendations please.

Your obedient servant,

Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Ottawa, March 24th, 1931.

Sir,-

I have to acknowledge the receipt of the voucher which you forwarded, in favour of A. A. Morrison, for supplies furnished for the use of the Salmon River Indian Day School to the amount of $8.92. This account contains an item covering the cost of thirty-six (36) lead pencils to an amount of $1.08. In this connection, I beg to say that all supplies of this nature should be requisitioned for by the teacher. She should anticipate her requirements for all classroom supplies such as text books, stationery, pencils, etc., and prepare a requisition on the form provided for that purpose, same to be certified by the local Indian Agent and forwarded to the Department, when these supplies will be ordered through the Government Stationery Office here and sent to the teacher's address.

In future, except in the case of an emergency, payment cannot be made for supplies such as lead pencils and other classroom material purchased locally. I have to request that you will advise both the local Indian Agent and the teacher accordingly. The account which you submitted will, in this case, be paid as soon as funds are available, which will be in April, next.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I beg to report to you that I have inspected the Indian Day School, Chapel Island Reserve, and must say that there is considerable improvement there since the appointment of a new teacher at that school.

The teacher, Miss MacDonald, will instruct the children in sewing and knitting which I consider is very important in the education of the Indian. In connection with this work would you kindly authorize the purchase of the following articles:

- 2 webs flannelette
- 3 doz spools white thread
- 5 pkgs needles
- 5 lbs. 4 ply knitting yarn
- 15 sets knitting needles

The ground outside the building needs several loads of gravel. If this were supplied the floor of the school would not get so dirty during wet weather. Approximately $15.00 would be required to do this work.

As usual the toilets were in need of cleaning.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, December 4, 1931.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 24th ultimo, regarding the teaching services at the Salmon River Indian Day School, and giving a list of the materials required for the purpose of teaching sewing and knitting to the pupils.

In reply I have to say that the Department is pleased to note the improvement in the work at this school under the charge of Miss MacDonald. As she will undertake the instruction of the pupils in sewing and knitting, you may arrange for the purchase and delivery of the following materials: 2 webs flannelette, 3 doz. spools white thread, 3 packages needles, 5 lbs. 4-ply knitting yarn and 15 sets knitting needles.

You may also arrange to have several loads of gravel placed around the grounds outside the building. This gravel should be properly graded. It is noted that the cost of the gravel will be approximately $15.

After the sewing material has been purchased and the work in hauling and levelling the gravel has been completed, you should forward accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred.

Ottawa, November 16, 1932.

Rev. Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of the communication which you forwarded from Miss Tina MacDonald, teacher of the Salmon River Indian Day School, requesting that supplies be furnished for the midday lunch to the pupils.

In reply I have to say that, as our funds this year are extremely limited, it will only be possible to authorize an expenditure not exceeding the sum of $8 per month during the period from December 1st, next, to April 30th, following - five months. The supplies for the lunch should consist of milk, cocoa and sugar, and if funds permit, biscuits and cheese. Itemized accounts, in triplicate covering the expenditure incurred should be obtained, and these you should attach to proper voucher forms, certify in the usual manner and forward for payment from time to time.

Regarding the teacher's request to be allowed a grant to purchase candy and fruit for a treat for the pupils at Christmas, I have to say that you may incur an expenditure which must not exceed the sum of $8 for this purpose. Please obtain an itemized account, in triplicate, covering the cost. This you should attach to a proper voucher form, certify in the usual manner and forward for payment.

You may also arrange for the purchase of 6 pounds of yarn, to be made up by the pupils. An account, in triplicate, properly certified, should be forwarded covering this expenditure.

Regarding the request that a pair of gum shoes and stockings for each pupil and two webs of flannelette be supplied, I have to request that you will state the number of pupils for whom the shoes and stockings are absolutely necessary. If any of the Indian parents are able to supply the shoes and stockings required, they should do so. If possible, you should furnish an estimate of the total cost involved in supplying the shoes and stockings, also the cost of two webs of flannel-ette. When we have this information, consideration will be given as to whether approval can be granted for the expenditure or not.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Dear Sir,

I have heard former teachers at this school make complaints about the poor heating qualities of the furnacette in use there. I have examined the heater recently and I am quite sure it is not a satisfactory heater and I do not believe it will work.

My idea of a heater for schools in this section of the country is a coal stove of the type used by the railways for heating R.R. Stations commonly called the "box" fires from their shape.

Dear Sir,

In reply to your letter of October No. 60-1-5 I wish to inform you I visited the Salmon River Indian Day School on Nov. 9th and looked over improvements suggested by Inspector J.A. Bennett.

In order to place two additional windows in the south wall as proposed it will be necessary to rearrange the windows there now so there is not room to place an additional window between those already there. This means that this wall will have to be stripped, studding moved to accommodate new windows and probably new studding may be needed. This is an old building and it is difficult to say just what may have to be done.

Other windows are removed it will be necessary to plaster - the interior of this building is plastered.

This new work will have to be painted and for that reason you will have to paint the entire building both interior and exterior. The painting is badly needed anyhow.

I also find the wall under the building is in very poor condition.
Sir,

I would like to suggest that if you go on with the other repairs that a cement wall be placed under the building. In connection with moving the windows I forgot to state that new sashes will have to be purchased and possibly window frames.

My estimate for the carpenter work including material, replacing the plaster including necessary material ($200.00) two hundred dollars.

To put a cement wall under building sides and material ($50.00) fifty dollars. To paint building inside and out, all new wood to have two coats labor and material ($50.00) fifty dollars.

Of course you will understand I am not an expert at estimates and as I said before it is difficult to know just what you may run into when you start repairs on a building as old as this—perhaps find a better bill. However, I think this estimate will come very close to completing this work.

Will you kindly tell me in what year this building was constructed?
Sir,

Now I believe the time to do this work is when school closes for the summer vacation—July 1937.

MEMORANDUM:

DR. MCGILL.

Salmon River Indian Day School (Richmond County).
Teacher: Miss Hazel I. Bissett.

Owing to the fact that I was very busy on this Reserve and as I had arranged a meeting with the Indians at the school, I did not have an opportunity of discussing the school work at any length with the teacher. However, I had a short chat with her.

The school building (18' x 25') is in poor condition, and I came to the conclusion that it is very doubtful if it is worth repairing. It was built many years ago and as far as I could make out the foundation is pretty well gone, as well as the sills under the floor. However, I could not properly examine the foundation, as there is no basement under the school. I would suggest, if any requests come in for extensive repairs, that the Department first ascertain whether or not the building is really worth spending very much money on in the way of repairs.

The ceiling is badly in need of paint, as I do not suppose it has been painted for years.

I noted that the seats are very old and rickety.

More blackboard space is required at this school.

The average attendance is 23 - Grades from I to VI.

General Superintendent of Indian Agencies.

Dear Sir,

Attached is form with estimates for next fiscal year as requested. The $50.00 is for possible repairs to Coal Shed and toilet. They will likely have to be shingled in 1939.

On October 1936 Inspector Benoit recommended some changes made in the lighting of the Classroom of the Palmer River Indian Day School. An estimate was made of the cost and submitted to the Department.

This building is more than 50 years old and it is very doubtful if it is worth remodeling. I think we should have a new school building and use the old building for a hall. As you know their Council House is on the Island where their Church is and it is not always convenient to go over there.

I have felt for some time that my
Indian Affairs should have a community hall centrally located on the main land. The old school building would fill the bill very nicely. I did not make an estimate of the cost of a new school would be. I pray that you give this proposition every consideration.

It is a well-known fact that the old building is very unsatisfactory and I sincerely hope the estimates for the next fiscal year will include an appropriation for a new school on this reserve.

I enclose building data form which you should carefully complete and return to me as soon as possible. The Department favours a one-roomed school with full basement in which there would be accommodation for manual training. It is understood that a teacher can obtain boarding accommodation reasonably close to the school and under these circumstances it is not considered necessary to provide living quarters for the teacher.

Memorandum:

With reference to your memorandum of the 24th instant regarding the building proposed for the above, I am forwarding herewith, in duplicate, a sketch plan (Scheme A) of a building of the type which will provide the accommodation requested, namely, one classroom to seat 36 pupils with full basement.

You will note, however, that the classroom shown on this plan is for 40 pupils. I may say that a variation of 5 pupils can readily be made by eliminating one row of seats and reducing the length of the classroom by 2'6". I would be pleased, therefore, to be advised whether accommodation for 35 pupils will be satisfactory in place of the 36 requested. If not, it is recommended that a building of the size shown be erected.

The cost of the building providing accommodation for forty pupils is estimated at about $5,100.00, and for 35 pupils at about $4,800.00.

Dear Sir:

I desire to refer to your letter of the 6th ultimo in connection with the proposed new day school on the Salmon River Reserve.

I note your suggestion that the old school building be moved across the road in order that it might be used as a community hall.

Our experience has been that unless the use of a community hall is carefully supervised either by a missionary or a teacher it is more likely to become a nuisance than a benefit to the Indians on the Reserve. I would, therefore, suggest that you give the matter further consideration and let me have your views. If you still think that a community hall is desirable you might let me know the approximate cost of moving the building.

Do you recommend that the new school be erected on exactly the same location as the present school or could it be erected on some other part of the school site? Incidentally you might let me know the approximate size of the school site.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the first instant, in which you again suggest that the Indian school building at the Chapel Island reserve, in your agency, be transferred to the Indians for use as a community hall.

The officials here have learned from experience that community halls, unless they are under the direct and immediate supervision of an Indian agent or missionary, or perhaps both, are apt to create unnecessary strife and confusion on an Indian reserve. In view of this fact, therefore, we believe that the old school should be dismantled and the lumber distributed among the Indians for the repair of their houses.

It is just possible that on your recommendation, from time to time, the new school might be used for a certain number of band meetings. The attitude of the Department, when requests for the use of the school reach us, will depend almost wholly upon your recommendation.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,

The Deputy Superintendent General:

Re appointment of teacher for the new Indian school, Sydney, C.B.

There are about 18 Indian families living in the town of Sydney on a small reserve of about 2½ acres for the education of whose children a new schoolhouse has been built and equipped. These Indians have about 25 children of school age and provision is made for the salary of a teacher at the rate of $200.00 per annum, this being the lowest amount paid in the Lower Provinces and $300.00 the highest. The average salary is $250.00.

Mr McLean, in his report on the Indians of Cape Breton, states that Father McAdam, the Agent, could obtain the services of a lady who would be willing to devote her life to uplifting the Indians, and he placed the salary at $200.00, which seems a small amount for the weight to be raised. As however, $300.00 is the limit to which the Department has seen fit to go, I do not see how that amount could be exceeded without creating a precedent for the payment of larger salaries to all of our schools.

These Indians lives in miserable shacks and are said to be in a very wretched condition, although there is plenty of work at good wages to be
If the Department desires to pay the teacher more than $300.00, the only way that I can see that it could be equitably done would be to give her additional duties outside of the school similar to those performed by a Field Matron in the United States, and pay her accordingly.

OTTAWA, 9th December, 1903

The Deputy Superintendent General:

With reference to the letter of the 17th ultimo from the School Commissioners of the Town of Sydney, in which they state that they have been asked to undertake the supervision of the Indian school on the Reserve there, I beg to say that Rev. Mr Macadam, who was asked to state who made this request, and what form the supervision is to take, reports that it originated with Miss Connolly, the teacher, who would benefit by such an arrangement to extent of an additional $110.00 in her salary out of the Provincial grant. The school would, however, have to be placed virtually in the hands of the School Commissioners as, under the Public Instruction Act of Nova Scotia, the provincial grant cannot be paid to the teacher of any school which does not come under the control of a board of trustees.

If the Commissioners are willing to assume the control of this school, I do not see that there ever was any necessity for starting it as the Indian children could have gone to a white school upon payment of tuition. The Department has the benefit of the Public School Inspector's visits in Nova Scotia for which we already pay, and it seems to me that the proposed arrangement is solely for the benefit of the teacher. Of course this school is peculiarly situated
being in the town of Sydney and it might not form a precedent for other teachers to ask to have their schools placed under the control of white trustees, but as there is already a good deal of dissatisfaction at the withdrawal of the provincial grant from Indian teachers, they may be expected to do their best to have the terms of the Provincial Act met, so that they might get the benefit of the grant. Miss Connolly is now receiving a good deal more than any of the teachers in the Lower Provinces and the others are likely to complain of unfair treatment if a further increase is made to her salary.
