Teachers' Normal Institute

FOR THE

Six Eastern Counties of Nova Scotia.

Sydney, C. B., December 20th to 23rd, 1909.

The fourth session of the Teachers' Normal Institute for the Six Eastern Counties of Nova Scotia will be held in the City of Sydney commencing on the 20th day of December, 1909. This date has been selected as, perhaps, when everything is considered, the most suitable in the term. It is a time when school work is somewhat relaxed and when the closing of the schools for a week will not interfere appreciably with the progress of the pupils. On account of Christmas falling this year on Saturday there will be only three days for Institute work and it will in consequence be necessary to have a teaching session on one of the afternoons. But it is hoped that by extending the sittings a little and by shortening the lessons to a small extent nearly as much ground can be covered in three days as used to be covered in four days on former occasions.

The work of the Institute will again consist mainly of teaching exercises as the time-table indicates. For these the very best teachers obtainable will be secured. By means of a question box or similar arrangement all those present will be given opportunities to make any inquiries they may wish regarding teaching, school management, school law or any other matter in any way connected with school affairs. Times, of which ample notice will be given, will be set apart for the answering of these inquiries. It is expected that this feature of the session will prove of great value to everybody concerned and all are strongly urged to avail themselves of it. It would be a good idea for teachers from now onward to make notes of the points regarding which they may require advice or enlightenment. A number of the most prominent Provincial educationists will be invited to attend and to assist in this and other departments of the work. On one of the evenings a meeting open to the public generally will be held at which addresses on educational topics will be delivered by competent persons.

It may not be amiss to remind the teachers of the Counties interested that this Institute has been devised and is maintained solely for their benefit. The Inspectors who have charge of it are obliged, as one of their duties, to have a session held every second year. Their single purpose in the whole matter is to assist the teachers of their Divisions and, this being so, they expect that every teacher will render all the aid possible, in making every meeting a success. A few teachers will be entrusted with the conduct of the specimen lessons. A few will have to attend to the providing of classes and of accommodation for visitors. But of the great majority of teachers in the territory concerned nothing is asked except their attentive presence at the sessions. Teachers with no training or little experience are urged to attend, if at all possible, in order that they may learn; those whose ability is recognized are asked to come mainly that they may help along a worthy cause. But it may safely be predicted that every teacher whether of great or little experience, who shall come determined to play an earnest part in the work, will find ample opportunity for profitable employment.

The time necessarily lost from their schools by those who attend will, as usual, be allowed as regards payment of Provincial Aid and Municipal Fund. It is hoped that school boards will encourage their teachers to be present as improved work during the balance of the term will compensate many times over for the four days lost.

The usual arrangements respecting reduced fares on railways and steamboats will be made, if possible. Those who travel by the I. R. C. should get single tickets and a standard certificate. On small local lines, stage, rail or boat, it would be well for teachers to ask their own inspectors to make the necessary arrangements.

Those who wish to have accommodations provided for them in Sydney will save themselves probable inconvenience by communicating with Mr. A. W. Woodill, Principal of the Central School, Sydney, C. B., Chairman of the Local Committee, at least a week before the opening of the session. Teachers who travel by the I. R. C. will be met at the station Monday evening.

A. G. MACDONALD,
Chairman of the Executive Committee.

Secretary Department of Indian Affairs

Replying to your letter No. 225264 dated Ottawa March 17th, 1910, I desire to acknowledge receipt of copy of regulations regarding Compulsory attendance of Indian children at School. While it is most desirable that Indian children attend school where schools are provided for them, and while I regret very much that the attendance is not better at the Sydney School, which affords every facility being only a few hundred yards from the children's quarters away from it, yet I fear that the putting in force of the Act would not have the desired effect. In the first place, I find that my Indians are not inclined to turn a finger without being paid and a Trust Officer would have to be employed at a Salary, and his work might not be very satisfactory after all. There are various reasons for irregularity in School attendance at the Sydney School, for the past year or so labour around Sydney has been scarce and the Indians own have no chance to earn much, as a consequence the...
Indian women have to go out to wash and scrub in order to make a living, and when there is a baby or one or two very small children, the school going children have to stay home to mind them. The Indian women on this reserve are more industrious than the men but that they have to go out to work has a bad effect on the children as well as on the housekeeping generally. I believe that if the payling that would necessarily be paid to a truant officer were offered in the shape of small prizes for regular attendance at school, that the result would be better. I shall do you suggest endeavor as much as possible to stir up more interest in the parents and impress upon them the importance of sending their children regularly to school, and if those efforts fail, then it might be judicious to give the Compulsory Act a trial.

Yours very respectfully,

Dear Sir,

I write concerning the Indian School at Sydney.

Miss McKeown, the present teacher, had always understood that if she intended to leave at any time, she was to give me three months' notice in advance. She went away at the beginning of vacation and on her return when all the schools were reopened and practically all the teachers available were engaged, she informed me that she was in poor health and would have to resign but suggested I look for a substitute a younger sister of hers who holds only a Third Class provincial license but who has taught school for one year. I told Miss McKeown that I was not disposed to take a teacher who held only Third Class and expressed my displeasure at her not giving me timely notice. I told her also to finish this quarter which ends August 1st and that by that time I would probably have another teacher.

Now, at this very time all the experienced teachers are engaged as the school year begins Sept. 1st. But there is a young lady living quite close to the Indian School (Miss Edna Gough) who took a first class license at the provincial examination last July. She is about nineteen years of age and a very clever girl, she never taught a public school, but she graduated from the Convent here in Sydney last Summer with high honors. She is willing to teach the Indian School for the same salary that Miss McKeown was getting viz., four hundred and fifty dollars a year. I think she would probably take four hundred if I said so, and I feel quite confident from my knowledge of her that she will give general satisfaction.

Please let me know as soon as possible if I may engage her.

I should strongly recommend that a trained officer be appointed on the scene when the School re-opens. Every other effort has been put forth both by myself and the teacher to get the children to attend school and when it is a fact that there are 25 school going children on the reserve, all of whom are within gunshot of the school house and the average daily attendance over two years higher than 8 or 9, it is clear that efforts of ridicule have failed to produce satisfactory results. Therefore it is that I believe in some stringent measures being taken, the parents of these children are in most cases fairly comfortable and could easily without inconvenience themselves pay a small fine if they incurred the penalty.

And an example of this might come from a very palatable lesson.

I believe all the more that the children do not attend school because at school I have continued in former efforts. The boys who attend the school and they attained to the 4th grade, are giving a good account of themselves by being industrious, ambitious and of good conduct. As requested by your letter of the 22nd ultimo, I visited Sydney this week, and having investigated matters affecting the Indian school there, found the situation substantially as described by Revd. D. A. MacAdam in his letter of Aug. 17th. to the Department.

I would say that the Agent was unfortunate in having appointed last year such a teacher as Miss Hines proved to be, but I do not think he should be condemned for that, because she was duly qualified and well recommended. Nor can he be blamed for her failure as a teacher, or for her moral character, which was very bad; but he may not have been vigilant enough in his supervision of her work in school, as, otherwise, she would have been dismissed sooner than she was.

GENERAL REMARKS.

The great obstacle to progress in Indian Schools which I visit is the fact that the children know so little about English, and as they never attempt to speak it among themselves at school or at home, improvement is very slow. Teachers should endeavour to get them to talk more in class, particularly in discussing the meaning of the words and phrases in the reading lessons. Where their powers of observation and memory have room to play they are apt to do really well. For instance they spell as well as white children and usually their writing is good. The same may, I think, be said of drawing where it is taught. They do not appear to be much good at geography, but most of the people I meet are not sufficiently advanced to take up this subject.

Female principals, holding Grade B, in charge of 10 or more departments should receive $1000.

Male principals, holding Grade B, in charge of from 7 to 9 departments should receive $750.

Female principals, holding Grade B, in charge of from 7 to 9 departments should receive $700.

Male principals, holding Grade B, in charge of less than 5 departments should receive $725.

Female principals should receive a yearly salary of $150 for successful service up to five years.

We respectfully recommend that the salary of the teacher of electives and expression be increased to $750 per annum. The salary of the supply assistant, who has to do much substituting work, be advanced to $700 per annum. In the absence of the principal, he has to shoulder the care and responsibility of all the eighty odd common school departments should be increased by $100.

**Academy Increases.**

In regard to the Academy, we would recommend that Principal Creedman, Vice Principal Ellis and Mr. Archibald be granted an increase of $150 per annum. Because they hold Academic licenses, that they be paid $150 per annum each. These are as these may be present pressing needs which it would be unprofitable to delay. We further state that, if this report is adopted, the payments begin with the next cheque issued by the Board dating from January 1, 1919.

All of which is respectfully submitted.

**Committee Files Report.**

At the January meeting your Committee reported progress and was instructed to make further investigation. After full and careful investigation we have come to certain findings which we hereby submit to the approval of the Board. We desire to state that there is no more important duty devolving upon us than the proper moulding of the young for future usefulness as citizens we teach. We believe that the best way to do this is in this meritorious work and do it satisfactorily. We desire to give our earnest reward in material and moral support.

To qualify for the teacher's position requires hard and constant preparation. The work itself calls for the exercise of such a high degree of care, patience and skill that the success thereof is regarded as a public good and is regarded as a public asset of incalculable value.

During the past fifty years industrial conditions have been such that a large number of young men and women have found employment in the province as a respectable means of earning a livelihood. The result was that the demand and school sections acquired the habit of paying their teachers wages which were not commensurate with the services rendered. Industrial conditions have changed. Other industrial avenues to higher rewards have been opened so attractive, that many communities bid farewell to the idea of maintaining a school. To compete face to face with the big cities is a difficult task. We must provide inducements in the form of an increased scale of wages.

**Provincial Authoritative Law.**

It is a matter of fact regretted that the provincial government when asked to add to the provincial grants to the various grades did not see fit to do so. It is a fact that the provincial establishment has multiplied far faster than the resources of the province. To realize the full benefit of the teachers' ability we must do what we can to remove the financial worries to make it unnecessary for them to engage in outside occupations. We must also secure them from the reproach of constituting the poorest paid profession.

After careful study and research, we find that the average individual teacher in the province, and particularly in the common schools, is forced to live and maintain a position of respectability. Most of them receive a provincial grant, sums varying from $420 to $670. There are those who receive $900 and running into cobs. Those who are getting a little more than $600 find it impossible to get ends meet. Laboring under these conditions it is too much to expect either that others will be available to fill their places when they leave or that the present teachers will be able to worry it out for a year or two, but would it not be better to provide the remedy. Incidentally we may say, that I am convinced that the janitors in eight of our public schools, who need no compensation for their labor, whose labor is entirely manual, receive larger pay than the highly trained experts in charge of the same classes.

**Salaries Paid as Present.**

At the present time we are paying salaries in the common schools, including an advance of $25 per annum up to five years service as follows:

- Grade D—Female $300 to $455
- Grade C—Female $400 to $525
- Grade B—Female $450 to $550
- Grade A—Female $400
- Grade A—Female $425 to $550

The above report was adopted unanimously by the school Board.

Sir:

The Department has received a communication from Chief B. E. Christmas, Sydney, N.S., requesting permission to use the school house for the holding of council and prayer meetings. Last March a complaint was received from the janitor of the school regarding the condition in which the building was left after these meetings, which were held three evenings a week during the Lenten season. I shall be pleased if you will inform the Department as to your views regarding the granting of the school building for the purpose of holding church service and council meetings. The Department hardly understands why it is necessary to allow prayer meetings in the school, as, no doubt, there is a church of the faith to which these Indians belong near enough for them to attend. Kindly state if these prayer meetings are conducted by a clergyman, and if it is necessary that they be conducted in the school building. The Department would offer no objection to the conducting of meetings for the benefit of the Band, provided smoking and spitting are not allowed, and the school is cleaned and put in good condition after these meetings. We will await your reply before deciding as to whether authority can be granted for the holding of the council meetings and church service in the school building. Your early reply will oblige,

Sir,

Referring to the contents of your letter of the 10th instant, I beg to report as follows:

1. - There being no councillor at Sydney Reserve besides Chief Christmas, I cannot understand what need there is of a place to hold council meetings, and consequently I do not think that his request in this case deserves consideration.

2. - So far as I am aware, no church service in the serious sense of the term is ever held in the school house. Members of the Sydney band, including Mr. Christmas as leader, have been assembling occasionally in the building to say prayers, with the result described to you by the janitor of the school as to the condition he always found the place after these devotions, and in view of the pittance he gets for the performance of his duties, which he discharges faithfully, I am not surprised that he has complained to you about the matter. I have no knowledge of these assemblies having been conducted on any occasion by a clergyman. At present there is almost strife between Chief Christmas, who has three or four followers, and the other members of the band. In view of this fact itself, I think the Department should refuse permission to use the school house as desired by him. Furthermore, there is a church of the faith (Catholic) to which Sydney Indians belong within a short distance of their reserve, and they are at liberty to use it any time between sunrise and sundown for devotional exercises.

Ottawa, December 20, 1913.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of requisitions for the salary of Miss Margaret Hines, teacher of the Sydney School, for the September and December quarters.

A cheque for $140.00 is being sent to the teacher's address, being the amount of salary due her for the above period. She taught twenty days during the September quarter and is paid $40.00 for that time and a quarterly grant of $100.00 is allowed for the December quarter.

In this connection I beg to refer you to official letter of November 26th, last, in which you were requested to instruct the teacher to prepare a quarterly return showing the attendance of pupils for each of these two quarters. These returns did not accompany the requisitions for salary, but rather than withhold Miss Hines' salary till these returns are received the above named cheque has been sent her. A supply of these blank forms for quarterly returns are being sent you herewith and you will be good enough to have the teacher make out her returns for the September and December quarters and forward them to the Department at once. In future no salary will be paid until the quarterly returns are received.

Ottawa, July 2, 1914.

Madam,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of the June quarter return of the Sidney Day School, as well as a requisition for salary for the same quarter.

In reply to your request as to the amount of salary that you are paid, I beg to inform you that your salary is paid at the rate of $400.00 per year. The regulations require that day schools be kept open not less than two hundred days in each year. You were paid for 26 days during the March quarter, or $52.00, while for the June quarter you are being paid for 59 days, or $118.00. This completes your salary in full to the 30th ultimo. Should you remain at this school during the coming year your salary will be paid in equal quarterly installments of $100.00 per quarter.

I am enclosing a copy of the Indian Day School Regulations for your guidance.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, 22 July 1907

Please prepare plan and specifications for new school house at Sedley C.B. Similar to the one proposed in Middle River Victoria No.

[Signature]

[Handwritten note:]
Plan and specifications
Specifications for a School House to be built on
the Indian Reserve, at Sidney, C.B.

Description. A one story frame building on a stone foundation
30 ft by 22 ft, with a porch 5 ft by 10 ft. Height from
floor to ceiling 12 ft.

Foundation. Plain rubble masonry 16 in. thick 3 ft. 6 in.
high; 1 ft. above ground and 2 ft 6 in. below. The outside
walls are to be pointed above the ground. A centre wall
to support the floor joists 2 ft high; 1 ft above ground,
and 1 ft below, is to be built down the centre of the
building. 2 in planking to be laid along the tops of
all walls, and bedded in mortar to receive the joists.

Ventilators. Four iron ventilators are to be placed in the
outer wall; two on each side of the building.

Joists. Floor joists 2" X 10"; set at 2 feet centres.
One row of herring-bone braces to be put down through
the centre of joists on each side of the centre wall.
Ceiling joists are to be 2" X 8" set at 16 in centres.

Flooring. To be 1½ in dressed, tongued and grooved and
blind nailed.

Studding. 2" X 4" at 16 in centres; double at all windows,
doors and corners.

Wall Plates. 2" X 4" double.

Walls Outside to be of one inch rough boarding, tar
paper and drop siding. Inside lath and plaster; two
coats hard finish, except under wainscoting.

Wainscoting. To be put on the lathing after it has received
one coat of plaster. To be of double beaded sheeting 4 ft
high, well nailed to studding and lathing.

Ceiling. Lath and plaster. Two coats hard finish. A man-
hole 2 ft by 3 ft fitted with a cover, is to be placed
between the joists in the ceiling in the centre of the
building.
Roof

Rafters to be 2" X 6" at 2 ft centres; braces 1" X 6" to be well nailed on the rafters half way up. To be covered with rough boarding, tar paper and first class cedar shingles 4½" to the weather; surmounted with weather boards and roll. The eaves and cornice to be plainly finished with dressed one inch stuff.

Porch.

The foundation, joists, flooring and walls are to be the same as the main building. The rafters for the roof 2" X 4" without ceiling joists; braced half way up with 1" X 6" braces; these with the ends of the rafters will form the ceiling. Ceiling to be lathed and plastered with two coats hard finish; The roof to be covered the same as the main building.

Belfry.

A plain belfry is to be constructed on the roof at the front end of the building, as shown on the Plan. A hole for the bell rope is to be made through the roof, and the ceiling into the school room; both holes are to be boxed.

Chimney.

To be of well burnt brick one brick thick. To commence on the top of a cupboard 7 ft high. To be neatly finished above the roof, as shown on the Plan. To be well plastered within, and the portion in the schoolroom to be plastered on the outside, the same as the walls. A pipe hole with thimble, is to be placed in the schoolroom at two feet from the ceiling. To be fitted with a soot box and door.

Cupboard.

The sides and back of the cupboard are to be of 2" plank. It is to be fitted with shelves one foot apart, and provided with a plain battened door and lock.

Windows.

To be in two sashes; four lights 16 in square, in each sash. The upper sash fixed, the lower one to raise, to be fitted with proper fasteners. The gable is to have the circular window (or a square window) shown on the plan, unglazed, and fitted with plain 1" X 6" slats.

Doors
The two doors required at the porch and school-room are to be 2 in panelled doors 3 ft by 7 ft. The porch door is to have a fan light with two lights, as shown on the Plan.

Steps. To be built to the porch, as shown on the Plan.

Platform. The portion of the floor shown as the platform on the Plan, is to be raised 8 inches.

Blackboards. The spaces on the rear wall between the cupboard and each side wall, are to be painted on the plaster, with prepared blackboard paint, 3 ft 6 in high, from the top of the wainscoting.

Painting. Two coats of good linseed oil lead paint.

The outside white, with neutral tint facings. All inside wood work, light drab.

General. A good, plain, substantial building, complete in every respect, is to be erected, of sound materials, and good workmanship. It is to be subject to the inspection and approval of the Indian Agent in charge of the [illegible] Indian Reserve.

Dear Sir:

I was sick in bed when I received your communication re Indian School being built at Sydney. I have endeavoured to obtain the lowest possible figures for the construction of the building, and a reputable builder will undertake to put up the building without any surcharge whatever for less than $7000. Ottawa, September 13th, 1926.

Sir:

Miss MacDonald, travelling nurse for this Department for the Province of Nova Scotia, strongly recommends that a hot midday lunch be supplied the pupils of the Sydney Indian Day School each day, such meal to consist of hot soup or broth with biscuits, milk, cheese, sugar and cocoa. The preparation of this lunch in the school would serve a very useful educational lesson to the pupils. Besides, it will be of benefit to their health and encourage a more regular attendance.

I have to request that you will take this matter up with the teacher and ascertain whether she would, with the help of the older girls, prepare and serve this lunch. If she will agree to do so, you may purchase a small quantity of utensils for the purpose, such as individual graniteware cups, a kettle for boiling water, large sauce pan, dish pan and a small quantity of dish towelling. You may also arrange for the purchase of a small quantity of the following articles to be used in the serving of the meal, viz: biscuits, cocoa, sugar, condensed milk and cheese. The serving of this meal is to be provided during the fall and winter months only. The Department will expect you to see that no unnecessary expense is incurred in the purchase of these supplies. You should forward properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, covering the expense incurred.

We will expect to hear from you at an early date as to what arrangements you were able to make with the teacher for the preparing and serving of this lunch.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Referring to your letter of the 13th, Sept., I beg to advise you that the teacher of the Indian Day School at Sydney agrees to prepare and serve a hot midday lunch for her pupils, as recommended by Miss MacDonald, travelling nurse for the Department, and approved by you.

For that purpose I found it necessary to provide a closet or pantry, in which to keep under lock and key the necessary utensils, biscuit, cheese, condensed milk, etc., as otherwise these things might disappear somewhat mysteriously over night. The closet is now ready, and the serving of a midday lunch will begin about the middle of this month.

As a matter of economy, I think it would be advisable to purchase a bbl. of biscuit, which usually contains about 70 lbs., instead of buying a few lbs. at a time. But until I get your opinion in this respect, I shall procure a much smaller quantity to begin with.

Dear Doctor Scott,

The Department having decided to erect a school building on the new Indian reserve at Sydney, instead of moving the old school house there, would it not be well to begin the work of construction without delay, so that the building may be ready for use at the beginning of the ensuing school term - about the end of August.

If the plans for the building are not already prepared, I would suggest providing living quarters in it for the teacher, because it will be difficult to get a suitable boarding house within convenient distance of the reserve. A couple of small rooms would suffice.

I may say also that the Indians are anxious to have a basement to the building, which (basement) could be used by them as a hall or council house. I do not urge this feature.

Yours very truly,

Indian Superintendent.

July 11, 1927.

Sir,

I am sending you, under separate cover, two blue print copies of a plan of a combined day school and teachers' residence, which it is thought will be suitable for the new Sydney Reserve, and I would ask you to please arrange with Mr. Currie to have this building erected by day labour under the same arrangements as for the houses. The building should be erected to provide good drainage.

It is not thought necessary to place a basement under the building and the school can be heated by stoves. Before commencing operations I would ask you to have Mr. Currie examine the present old school building, with a view to using as much of the material out of this building as it is economically possible. No doubt the window frames, door frames, etc., can be worked in. The plan I am sending you is to be used as a guide but if you find that better use can be made out of the materials from the old building by making slight changes in the plans please do so. As the funds are limited I would ask you to please keep the cost of this building as low as possible.

Your obedient servant,

August 22, 1927.

Sir,

I enclose herewith Labour Return in duplicate, showing an expenditure of $419.03 during the week ended the 13th instant, on the new Indian reserve, Sydney, N. S., in the erection of a schoolhouse.

Work on this building is proceeding as rapidly as circumstances permit. Mr. Curry, construction foreman, did not think it advisable to use any of the material out of the old schoolhouse in the new one. He states that in his experience of forty years, as a contractor and builder, he found that putting old windows and doors in a new building invariably proved unsatisfactory. At any rate, he assured me that the new schoolhouse could not be completed, according to the plans, before the end of September; and knowing that school should open this date - the beginning of the 1927-28 school year - I decided to leave the old building intact and to use it until the new one would be ready for occupancy.

Chas. Marshall, already reported absent from Sydney, has not yet returned. I am endeavouring to locate him.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Superintendent.

Sir,

I enclose herewith Voucher No. 359A, amounting to $12.40 in favour of myself for services therein specified.

School has been in operation since the last week of October, inclusive, in the beautiful building recently erected for that purpose on the new Indian reserve at Sydney, and I have taken the liberty to appoint Peter Doucette janitor of the school, pending the approval of my action by the Department, but whether the appointment be confirmed or not, I recommend an increase of salary for the service which, in my judgment, should be $100.00 per annum, at least, because the duties in connection with the new school, including teacher's residence, will require more time, and much more attention, than was the case with the old Day School.

Doucette is not always able to do hard work on account of a chronic sore leg, which troubles him at times, but which is not of such a character as to interfere with the performance of his duties as janitor. He is in needy circumstances, and the income from this official position would be of very material assistance to him in providing for the support of his family. His home is one of the nearest to the school.

Your obedient servant,

H. J. Boyd,
Indian Superintendent.

Dear Sir:

Re Sydney School for Indians.

A day or two ago the writer made a rather complete inspection of the Sydney Reserve in company with Mr. A. J. Boyd, Superintendent, and we went through the school house.

Mr. Boyd advised me to write you with a view to having some new seating and desks installed in this school. The present seats are considerably out of repair, and are the old fashioned two seat benches.

If it is decided to install new seating it is suggested that single seats and desks be supplied.

Perhaps you have these at some other place and could ship them here, if not I shall be glad to get prices upon your instructions to do so.

We think about thirty seats will be sufficient.

The windows in the building are all on the cold
or North side of the building, and the teacher complains that it is difficult to keep the place warm during high cold north west winds.

Storm windows have been suggested, but the writer is of the opinion that weather stripping the windows would be more satisfactory in the long run.

These matters are submitted for consideration, and a reference to Mr Boyd may assist you in coming to a conclusion.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Ottawa, October 26, 1928.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 23rd instant, reporting the need of new desks for the use of the Sydney Indian Day School. In this connection I have to request that you will obtain prices from each of the manufacturers or dealers in school desks and submit them for the consideration of the Department. Rhodes, Curry, Limited, of Amherst, are manufacturers of school desks, and you should obtain a price from them and from any other manufacturers or dealers that you wish. It is noted that you state 30 single desks will be sufficient. The last return shows an enrolment of 28 pupils, with an average attendance of 19. School desks are manufactured in the following sizes:-

| No. | Size |
|-----|------|
| 1   | for adults |
| 2   | pupils 15 to 18 years |
| 3   | 11 " 14 " |
| 4   | 10 " 13 " |
| 5   | 7 " 9 " |

EXTRACT from report of Mr. Inspector Phelan, dated January 16th, 1929, on his inspection of the SYDNEY Indian Day School.

Original on File 61-1-6.

It would be advisable, I think, to supply good desks to this school. Those that are there were poor enough from the beginning and some of them are considerably battered. One indeed has only three legs and usually falls down when the pupils move from it.

The school building consists of a classroom, two entries, and a few rooms for the teacher. It is the property of the Dominion of Canada and nearly new. I am told the roof leaks. This should receive attention or the plaster will soon be spoiled. The classroom is on the north-western side of the building and never receives any direct sunlight during school hours. The building should have been placed so that the windows of this room would look to the south. This would make both for comfort and the health of the occupants. It is the correct way to light a school in these regions where there is hardly ever a warm day during the working term. Of course, this defect cannot readily be remedied now and the matter is mentioned mainly for the purpose of suggesting that plans for schools to be built in the future be referred to somebody experienced in details of this kind,—an inspector of schools being in general well qualified.

All the foregoing is offered in the hope that it may be of service and not for the purpose of adversely criticising anybody.
Ottawa, January 25, 1929.

Sir:

The Public School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Sydney Indian Day School, makes the following remarks regarding the new school building: "I am told the roof leaks. This should receive attention or the plaster will soon be spoiled."

This is a new building, having been erected in 1927, and it is not considered, if the shingles were properly laid, that there should be any leakage. However, I have to request that you will examine the condition of the roof and, if any repairs are required, you should arrange to have them carried out as soon as weather conditions permit in order to overcome the danger of any leakage and the consequent damage to the plaster. No unnecessary expense should be incurred. Accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, should be forwarded covering the cost of any repairs carried out. This matter should receive your prompt attention.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

Your 61-1-5 of the 25th Indian School at Sydney N. S.

I have just returned from an inspection of the school building in question, and cannot find any evidence of a leaky roof, or other part of this building.

I asked the teacher to show me what Inspector Phalen had seen, and which were the leaks complained of.

She pointed to some small stains which look to me like stains in the plaster, which have been there since the place was plastered, and I doubt very much if these stains have been caused by water getting in.

There is just one other explanation that might be given with reference to this, and it is that some time ago, considerably over a month, we had a terrific gale of wind with very heavy rain from the south-west, and a good many dwellings in this city which have not leaked before, or since showed some signs of dampness after that storm, and there is a possibility that the wind was so high
that it raised the shingles which I notice are of the spark-proof variety of rubberoid, and not very stiff. This coupled with the fact that the roof at this point is very nearly level, would make it easy for the wind to get under these shingles and raise them in an exceptionally heavy gale such as we have had.

I do not know whether I have made the situation clear to you or not, but in any case I do not think that there is any reason to believe that any damage will be done to the building as it seems to me to be in very good shape, both inside and out.

I will have a carpenter up there within a day or two now installing the new seats, and I will get his opinion with reference to the roof.

What is to be done with the old seats, they only seem to be fit for firewood?

Yours truly,

Dear Sir:

Some time ago the matter of having some crushed slag placed around the Indian Day School building at Sydney, was under consideration, and the writer was asked to obtain a figure for placing a suitable quantity of this material on the ground.

In company with a friend of mine, who is our City Engineer, the writer walked over the site on a recent afternoon, and we have come to the conclusion that it will require from twenty to twenty-five tons of slag to make a satisfactory covering.

Dear Sir;-

Re Indian School, Sydney N. S. -

When at the Indian School today I noticed two or three small spots in the ceiling where leaks were showing through.

These are small spots and have done no damage yet other than slightly stain the ceiling, but they are the outcome of a high wind and rain storm.

The high wind lifts the shingles and the rain gets in under them, and it looks as if we would have to do something to prevent the shingles blowing up.

I have been speaking to a contractor today, and he tells me that outside of reshingling the roof the only thing that can be done is to go over the roof with a material known as "Stop a Leak" which is a mastic preparation, and stick down each row of shingles.

To do this would cost in the vicinity of $50.00

The shingles used were of a very light material
and they were applied I understand at the wrong time of the year, that is to say after the hot weather had passed.

You will remember in former correspondence it was hoped that the hot weather of this year would complete the sticking process, but unfortunately this does not seem to be the case.

The shingles used on this roof have been replaced in the trade here altogether the last year or two by a much stiffer shingle known as "Heavy Butts".

Subject to your judgement I am recommending that the sticking down of each row be undertaken at once, in order to protect this fine little building, and if you wish a more exact figure as to cost, and wire me, I will obtain one and telegraph you at once.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

I received word by phone at noon today that the stove pipe at the Indian School had given out, and took a stove man up there at once and arranged to have it fixed tomorrow morning.

Dear Sir;-

Your favour of the 5th inst 61-1-5 on the subject of heat for the Sydney Indian Day School has been received.

When at the school today I discussed the matter with the teacher, and she informed that on very cold days in the winter, it was once in a while hard to keep the room up to the required heat. My own opinion is that they let the fire get low. The stove man who was with me stated to me that the stove at present in the room should give ample heat for a room of the size in a building of as good construction as the school house is.

During last Winter I frequently asked the teacher if the room was comfortable and her answer was invariably "yes."

It seems that Miss McDonald the travelling has told her that the Public Health Dept. has approved of only one type of heating apparatus known as a "Jacketed Heater" at least that is what she called it.

I am attaching here to a cut of the kind of furnace that is being installed in the modern schools, with attachment for a cold air supply. If this patent arrangement is installed, the pipe for the outside air could be put into the basement directly behind the furnace, and so led to the fresh air outlet in the side of the wall, that is to say, the furnace stands in the school room and the cold air pipe could be put through the floor to lead as above.

This furnace installed would cost $105.00 in Sydney. A larger and better heater than the present one but with no cold air attachment could be installed for $55.00. There should be some allowance for the old stove. If a change is made I would recommend the $105.00 job.

Yours truly,

Sir:

Replying to your letter of the 14th instant, I have to say that the Department will approve of the serving of a hot lunch to the various Indian schools in your inspectorate, the same as was done last year. The schools at which this lunch was supplied to the pupils were as follows:

- Eskasoni, Indian Cove (Pictou Landing)
- Sydney, Afton,
- Whycoomagh, Salmon River.

The supplies for the lunch should be of the same type and approximately in the same quantities as last year. You may inform the various agents, arrange with them to purchase the articles and have the teachers start the serving of the lunch from the middle of November, next. They may continue serving lunch to the pupils at these schools until the end of April, 1932. All expenses in connection with the purchase of the supplies required should be kept as low as possible. Itemized accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, should be forwarded, covering the expenditure incurred in this connection for each school, separately.

Sir:

Sir:

Dear Sir:

It appears that there has been some correspondence between the Dept. and Mr McNeil with reference to cleaning the ceilings and walls of the Indian Day School at Sydney.

It further appears that he has made a recommendation to the Dept. to have the heating stove in this school moved over against the wall to shorten the length of stove pipe required, and do away to some extent with the sooting of the walls due to the escape from the long pipe required as the stove stands now.

I looked at this school a day or two ago, and I am afraid that if the stove is placed over against the wall that the heat will not be so well distributed as it is from its present position in the centre of the room, and the stove pipe will stand in front of one of the blackboards.

The ceilings and walls are pretty badly darkened in the class room, but I believe that they would do for another season without cleaning, when perhaps the work could be undertaken of making a thorough cleaning of the room and furniture, as I am of opinion that another year the seats and desks would be the better of a coat of varnish, although they hardly require it now.

If the stove is to stand as at present, before school opens we will require to have 10 links of new stove pipe and three elbows 2 of 90 degrees and one of 45.

New knobs are required on one door, and the out buildings are in need of repairs to doors, some of which have been broken, and require new pieces set in, and some of the hasps are missing and should be renewed.

In front of one of the out-buildings they have shoveled the earth from in front down into the hole, and a platform of rough poles or plank should be put in here, as the door, due to the ground being shoveled away, is hardly accessible for the smaller children.

With attention given to these things the school should do another winter I should think without much expense.

Kindly advise what you wish done.

Yours truly,

S.E. Mingah.

On Friday night and Saturday the Island of Cape Breton was visited with a very severe gale of wind, but only slight damage was done to the property at the Indian Reservation.

The rubberoid roofing on the Day School out building was ripped off, and another small out building attached to one of the dwellings was overturned. Dear Sir:

Re Basement Windows in School

There are three windows, on the basement of the School, here. They have no protection, or any kind, and, very naturally, they are broken. The School needs them, for a minimum of light and ventilation. The School is heated by a Furnacett, placed not in the basement but on the first floor. Therefore, there is not any source of heating in the basement; and cold drafts, and weather coming underneath, up through the floor, is bad for the kids. It is also responsible for waste of fuel; and, a possible entry from outside for persons - or cats, rats, etc.

Repairs to the window: six new glass, would cost about $6.00. Two wood movable shutters, and one heavy metal screen one, (at the coal window) could be purchased at $5.00, each, with steel hooks and eyes.; ready made. To fit the shutters into place would take about a day (it is slow work fitting anything on to a cement wall). Steve Gould a handy man on the reserve would do that for two dollars. Truckage etc., perhaps two dollars. Total between seventeen and eighteen dollars.

I would not call it an emergency, but certainly a necessary matter. I leave it to the discretion of your Department.

Yours Truly,

[Signature]

Dear Sir:

The furnacett in Membertou Day School:

There are so many kinds of furnacett now, that it is very difficult, on short notice, to procure repair parts — especially in Cape Breton. With reference to this repair, I was obliged to pick up a part here, and another there, until we got the lot together, and I had to pay for them as we went along. Two of the grates had to come from St. John, N.B., also went good for the amount of his labour to the plumber, Mr. Christmas, at a local store, in advance. The telegraph Co.'s receipt is attached, for the night letter, which I also paid. Therefore, the ok. may come to me, I trust, within reasonable time; my own spare cash is too little.

On taking the furnacett apart, it was found that the fire-lining is worn out. It should have been cemented a year ago, and done over lightly, every year, — only a very small job, — in order to save the lining and keep it intact. Since that has not been done, the lining is now worn through. The final result will be that the casing of the heater will melt and warp, and a complete new one will behave to go in. Mr. Christmas while he had the furnace cold, patched up the lining, to save the casing as best possible, for the balance of this term. When warm weather comes in, there should be a new lining put in. It must come from St. John; and the job would cost approximately $25.00. Furnacetts are, so far, a chronic nuisance.

Yours truly,

This school was erected in 1927. The interior hasn't been painted; the walls, ceilings, and woodwork are very dirty and discoloured from coal smoke from the furnacette. If at all possible, the building, inside and out, should be painted during the summer holidays.

The furnacette is not satisfactory; parts are burned out and cannot be replaced; the top is cracked allowing the smoke to fill the classroom. It should be replaced with a suitable coal stove. New pipes are needed. It may do service for the balance of the winter but no longer.

The teacher has never occupied the residence. It was suggested that a reliable married Indian might be permitted to live in it in return for his services as janitor. The building would be better occupied if the right type of Indian is available and if such an arrangement wouldn't interfere with the teacher's classroom work. The grounds are used in the evenings by the younger set for ball games and windows, doors, and door knobs are constantly being damaged.

Inspector.
Ottawa, March 12, 1935.

Sir,-

The Department is in receipt of Inspector McGookin's report regarding his recent visit to the Sydney Indian Day School.

He states that it was suggested that an Indian might be permitted to live in the teacher's residence in return for his services as janitor. The Department has carefully considered this suggestion but, from our experience in other places, it is felt that this arrangement might prove very unsatisfactory and we are, therefore, not prepared to grant the permission requested.

Mr. McGookin states that the interior of the school requires decorating, also that a new coal stove will be required for next winter. Please let me know the approximate cost of decorating the interior of the school, also the cost of a new coal stove. When this information is received, the Department will be in a position to decide if funds for the purpose are available.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Joseph MacKinnon, Esq.,

Dear Sir:

The enclosed account for this work is nearly ten dollars less than the estimate submitted, and authorized, in your latter of Feb. 12, inst., 31-1-5.

The reason is that four window lights, one to each toilet, broken away, and included in the estimate, were not put in now, because it is certain that when renewing the roofs of these toilets, next summer, the hammering would shatter the glasses, and could not be avoided; the buildings are not heavily framed. That part can wait until the roofs will be renewed, as I described in another letter, some time ago.

Indian labour is always used on this reserve, when possible. But in this case, there is not any Indian who would do the work, without someone with experience to direct him; and two people around that little space would only be in each other's way, and make needless expense.

Dear Sir:

Re Indian School, Here, Yours, Mch. 12, ult. 61-1-5.

Your decision re a janitor to reside in the school, is based on the best of teachers, experience, and the advice shall be of good use to Agents. My hopes were prompted because of 1st, the saving of $60.00 2nd, to provide house for a family, much in need of it, and 3rd, to try and overcome petty mischief, about the building, a growing evil, the last year, with no constable, on the reserve.

About the Stove: I asked for twenty-five dollars, some time ago to repair the furnace, now in the school; and, later, for fourteen dollars, to change its position, both estimates were kindly approved. But, when I went and examined the furnace, carefully, I thought that I surely would not like to spend forty dollars of mine on it, for what it could be improved. The Chief and a few others to help changed its position, during the Christmas vacation, making no charge, for same, except a couple of elbows for the smoke pipe, and we saw it would carry for this winter, and then should be scrapped. I sought prices on something to replace it; and, am watching the success of a stove newly bought for another school, in a country section, not far away. By next summer, some such heater will be recommended, to you, and, then, I shall ask permission to divert the estimates already approved, to the new stove, and that will nearly cover the cost, if allowed.

As to cleaning the inside of the school, and putting up cracks, and painting, - the best price I have is from a first class man, living out in that direction, who has ladders and such equipment, and offers to do the work, including blackboards, for fifty five dollars. The seats ought to be done, also, although that is a matter of taste, stained and revarnished, for which he offers to do for nineteen dollars. This could be done at Easter, if approved.

Yours Truly,

MEMORANDUM:

DR. MCGILL.

Sydney Indian Day School (Cape Breton Co.).

Teacher: Miss C. Gallagher.

The average attendance at this school is 21. The teacher complained that most of the children leave school when they reach the age of twelve years or thereabouts. By then, they had only reached about the Fourth Grade.

The school inside looks very dingy - the walls are practically black - as no decorating has been done for years. It would be a step in the right direction if the school was either painted or kalsomined inside. There are many Indians there who could perform this labour.

The heater needs relining, as the present lining is pretty well burnt out, and the stove smokes badly.

There is a 22' x 30" lean-to built on to this school as a teacher's residence, but this is not used as the teacher lives in town. There is also a room upstairs, which is not used either.

A small coal bin was requested for the basement. At the present time, when the coal is put in, it is scattered all over the floor. I believe it would be more economical if a coal bin were built and there would certainly be less dust.

- Miss Gallagher
Miss Gallagher informed me that she had an appropriation of $8.00 with which she purchased sewing material. She said she appreciated this very much, as it enabled her to teach the children to make their own clothing, underwear, etc. She hoped that more material would be supplied later on.

Miss Gallagher has, I believe, been teaching at this school for possibly twenty years.

General Superintendent of Indian Agencies.
Ottawa, June 11th, 1937.

EX'D.

Dear Sir,

In reporting on his recent visit to the Sydney Indian Day School, Mr. M. Christianson, General Superintendent of Indian Agencies, reported that a small coal bin is required in the basement and that the heater needs re-lining. Please let me have an estimate of the cost of these repairs.

You might, also, state what expenditure would be involved in painting or kalsomining the interior of the school. On receipt of your reply, it will be decided if this work can be authorized.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

John H. Langley, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
St. Peters, N. S.
The boy's entrance to this school, is nearest the road, and therefore the one in common use, for general purposes. The schoolhouse is on the top of a small steep hill, sloping, hard down to the road, and the boys' door is on the steep side of the grounds, in a hard exposed corner. The ground has washed away some, so that the steps up to the door are dropped into an outward angle. It is a most disagreeable entrance, looks poor, and, in winter, is very dangerous. Boys have been hurt on it; and the parents of one youngster, their only child, have complained that his death was indirectly due to having been pushed off that step, in winter. I think it the duty of the agency to mention this.

I would have new steps replacing the old ones, and run alongside the wall of the building, instead of away from it, as at present, and the approach from the level side instead of up the decline. I would have some husky posts supporting the end of the steps, at the door, and a heavy guard rail of timber to prevent falling off.

The toilet building needs two doors. The estimate I have on the work, from a common sense carpenter, is $60.00. The work is fussy, and cannot be done by the Indians. Although not an emergency, I must say that it ought to be done; and I have put off referring to it since two years. Your valued instructions will be very welcome to me, in the matter.

Yours truly,

Mr. D. MacPherson, being sworn, says: I am Indian Agent for the Whydahawk Indian Reserve. On Tuesday and Wednesday, the 25th and 26th of last February I visited that reserve. I went to the Indian School accompanied by the Rev. Mr. Doyle. On the 25th it was not in session when we went there (between three and four o'clock), and I learned from the people that it had not been in session.
During the day, I did not see Mr. Murphy that
evening that occasion. On the 26th I visited the school
again, in company with Rev. Mr. Macdonald, but
found it as a chapel. We went there between 7 and
8 o'clock in the morning, and remained there until
about noon. I did not see Mr. Murphy, the school
teacher. The children did not come because
they knew that we were stopping there. The
school house was free during the afternoon but
I believe the school was held; indeed I know
it was not.

On a later occasion, on a visit to the school,
I looked upon the school register, and in appeal
to me that the register did not show that
the school was closed on those days. I believe
the register does not show that the school
was closed on those days.

I visited the Reserve on Oct. the 6th and
found that the school had been closed
for two weeks or thereabouts. It was closed
without my permission. I am not aware
For what cause I understand that Mr. Murphy was away at times from the school acting as surveyor on these occasions; however, Mr. Murphy, I understand often left a female substitute (whether always or not I do not know) to teach the school. I have never given him permission to absent himself or to employ a substitute during the three quarters I have had charge of the agency.

Cross Examination by Mr. Murphy.

Q. Are you positive that he was not there on Feb. 25th?

A. As far as I remember I was told that he was in school.

Q. Did you know that any person came to teach school on the 26th?

A. I had no such knowledge.

Q. Did you know that a young lady came to teach the school on the 26th?

A. I have no recollection.

Peter Burgess, Jr., sworn says: I am a Mi'kmaq Indian of Whigwam Reserve. I live on the
Reserve all the time. I remember the visit of Mr. MacKenzie to hold Easter service on the Reserve last spring. Remember the day when Mr. MacKenzie and Doyle came to the Reserve. I believe the school was open in the morning of that day, but cannot state positively. I do not know whether it was closed or open in the afternoon. I believe there was no school on the following day. Mass was held in the schoolhouse in the morning, and I believe there was no school in the afternoon, but cannot state positively. During the month of September I believe the school was closed on the 11th and 12th, and on the 15th, 16th, 17th, 18th, and 19th of the following week, all these days being school days. Stephen Thomas, sworn, says: I am an Indian of the Micmac band, belonging to the Weymouth Reserve. I remember the Rev. Mr. MacPherson and Mr. Eagle coming to the Reserve last spring for Easter services. I was not on the Reserve the day they arrived, but got home late in the evening. I do not know whether the school was open or closed that day. I went to the schoolhouse the next morning. It was about 9:30 when I left home and I went straight to the school, a quarter of a mile away, and began school. Mr. MacPherson and Mr. MacDonald (from Brook Village) were present. I remained until after the Mass, and it was about 12 o'clock when I left the schoolhouse. I then went home. I did not see Miss Austin again that day. I have a key which admits pupils. He did not go to school after Mass for there was no school. My key is irregular in attendance almost the time of the Halifax shipwreck.
Mr. Murphy had school on Wednesday and Thursday it was closed and he went away. I heard of the Hopedale exhibition. He was away on Saturday and the whole of next week until the Thursday there. He then taught school on Friday and the following Monday; then he went off again. Before he was away for a couple of days and the school was closed. Mr. MacBroom and Mac Donald were saying Mass on the occasion. Named I am their master came to the close of the school and then he away. The community voted a substitute for Mr. Murphy, the school teacher.

Mr. R. A. Murphy, section, says: I am the school teacher for the Otyantumah Indian Reserve. The Register for the last March and June quarter was left by me in the school desk and is not there now. It has not been destroyed by me. The Register I am using is the common school Register used in Nova Scotia. I do not use any Indian Department Register because I have never been supplied with one. I make a return to the Indian Department from the common school Register. I am paid by the Department of Indian Affairs two hundred and five dollars a year. I am also paid by the Provincial Education Office. The sum I receive from this source varies, but is about eighty-five (85) dollars a year. I have been drawing a grant from the Provincial Authorities for six or seven years. In addition to the Indian grant I make returns to the Provincial Educational Office.
Office every six months. There is nothing in the returns to show that the school is an Indian School. I do not know whether the Education Department owns the School as an Indian School or not.

I believe I am entitled to draw a grant from both the Dominion and the Provincial Authorities for the same school. I am a Provincial Land Surveyor, but for the last year I have done considerable surveying for the surveyed lands for the Crown Lands Department of Nova Scotia and Mining Roads for the Department of Mines. This work as a surveyor has caused me to be absent occasionally from school, but when so absent I have sometimes furnished a substitute, but not upon all occasions. When I do not furnish a substitute I close the school. During the past year I have only furnished a substitute (so far as I remember) once, for two days. I have twice as far as I remember closed the school without a substitute during last year, once from the 1st to the 15th of September, and once subsequent to the latter date, for three days. On the first occasion I went to Halifax on private business, and on the second occasion to survey some Mining Roads.

Mr. John MacKinnon being sworn, says: I am Inspector of Public Schools, and at the request of the Department of Indian Affairs inspect their schools on the Wabigoon Central Indian Reserve. I have done so for eight years. During that time I have inspected it twice a year, and occasionally oftener. Mr. Murphy has always been in charge since I commenced inspection. The progress during eight years has not been what might have been expected, but this was due first to unfavorable location of the school house, it being situated at the extreme end of the settlement, and second to irregular attendance. I have only a general knowledge of the school routine. I have never seen a time table, but infer from the text books used the subjects taught between one inspection and another the progress has not been such as it should have been.
If the school had been regularly attended, the order of the school is not what I would like to have it, but as good as I think it possible to have it with Indians. I have inspected the Register and have not seen anything in them that would lead me to believe that they have not been faithfully kept. I do not know how the school draws funds from both Provincial and Dominion governments, but they were doing so when I came here and have been doing so since. The Provincial Government is aware that it is paying the Indian school for it is shown in the statistics and returns.

Charge No. III. That P. A. Murphy got one child, Mac Isaac, of West Lake Annie, in child act of Wellwood.

Mr. Murphy states and produces a marriage certificate to show that justice was done in this case by him upon Sept. 15th last by his having married Miss Mac Isaac. Mr. Murphy further states that a child was born during the month of July last.
I return herewith File No.103,167-IA, to which has been attached the evidence taken in connection with charges against Mr. P.A. Murphy, teacher of the Whycocomagh Indian School and some correspondence in connection with the inquiry.

Father McPherson, the Agent, charges the teacher with not having the school open on certain school days; with failing to properly instruct the children and with having got one Rosie McIsaac of West Lake Ainsley in child out of wedlock.

The evidence goes to show that there was some reason for closing the school on two days particularly indicated by the Indian Agent but establishes the fact that on other days the school has been closed without permission and apparently without sufficient reason. It was formerly not uncommon also for the teacher to place a substitute in charge of the school whilst he was absent performing his functions as a land surveyor.

It is in my opinion sufficiently clear that the school has been closed frequently without proper authority from the Indian Agent without good excuse.

As to the second charge, the School Inspector says "the progress during eight years has not been what

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
"might have been expected, but this was due, first to unfavourable location of the school house, it being situated at the extreme end of the settlement and second, the irregular attendance.

"I have only a general knowledge of the school routine. I have never seen the time table, but infer from the text books used, the subjects taught. Between one inspection and another the progress has not been such as it should have been if the school had been regularly attended. The order in the school is not what I would like to have it, but as good as I think it is possible to have with Indians."

The width of the reserve is only about a mile and a half so that the extreme distance to be traversed to the school, when it was badly located, would not exceed that distance for any of the children of the reserve. The irregularity of the attendance at school may have been due, to some extent at least, to uninteresting teaching; and experience proves that the order in the Indian schools need be no less perfect than in those of whites.

The Agent and I examined the school, therefore, on October 16th and I have no hesitation in saying that the teacher's work has not been well directed or at all effective.

As to the third charge. The main fact is admitted. In July, a child was born and on September 15th some two months later Mr. Murphy married Miss McIsaac. It was stated by the Indians that a result of the teacher's conduct was that they were afraid to send their girls to school. It was also urged that marriage was practically compelled but I did not consider this of any importance. The question at issue was whether the teacher was one who was guided by the dictates of morality and his admission seems
seems to show that he was not.

It is my opinion that the interests of the Service and the Indians would be best served by dispensing with the services of Mr. Murphy and that the Indian Agent who evidently wishes to make the school successful should be asked to nominate his successor.

Inspector of Indian Agencies and Reserves.

Dear Sir,

Referring to the appointment of a teacher for the Indian School at Whyacrough, I have thrown some light on the subject.

I have your letter asking me to appoint Miss Doyle in the recommendation of Inspector, Mr. Kinross and myself, and previous to that you asked me to concern with the Inspector in hiring a teacher. Why is all this tomfoolery going through? I have more to do than chase up and down to whyacrough and write here and there when such things are useless. I have made trips to whyacrough through fourteen miles of slush when I could scarcely consider myself paid with a master's salary. You have asked me to act as your agent hereafter, but I have tried to do the best of my ability and when your department becomes suffused through my fault than I wish to be dismissed. I am doing my part conscientiously, guarding my words and trying to be faithful to my master. I shall not change though and I detest being made a tool of. Let business be business.

Who is this strange new personage? Have never heard of the gentleman. Where does he come from? When shall I address his appointment? Making this appointment over the appointment of the applicants already named is a very arbitrary way of doing business. Am I such a figure head? I think the Inspector was not well worth for my honest purpose. I wish to do well by your department and by
the Indians. I feel that I am entitled to an explanation of your extraordinary mode of procedure in this case and I ask for it. Please reconsider your latter step and reinstate Miss Doyle, who, I am sure, will give satisfaction.

However, if no further steps must carry the weight of things in dealing with your department let me know something about Miss Leman. This business is a mean scheme and shows another depthpoliticians will stop to secure their end.

Now, my dear sir, I feel that you should reconsider this matter and rise above this petty worshipping of party men. In the face of all that was done under your express orders I cannot see how you can turn around and cancel an appointment in your division. Satisfactory, have you received any complaints about Miss Doyle as a woman or as a teacher? If not why look so trusted. I feel confident that, when you consider that this affair is public property and may be discussed according to the wishes of the public, and an explanation asked in public, when you consider how very mean your action was; when you consider that a Department should not be swayed by a single man; when you consider many other circumstances connected with the affair, I feel confident, long that in the face of these things you will be pleased to reinstate Miss Doyle.

Assuming myself that you will not go back on your former appointments on such small matters as I imagine there are between the lines.

I remain

Your obedient servant,

Donald MacPherson, R.P.

Dear Sir,

Permit me to say a few words in reply to your letter of 13th inst. From what you say I notice that my request for an explanation by your Department's way of dealing with the appointment of a teacher for the Wyandotte Indian School has at least been acknowledged. That done is something and perhaps sufficient as those who knew why a former appointment was cancelled. It is all cleared up now for the present teacher is a nephew of one who must be reckoned with. Now, my dear sir, I trust you will not consider me too horrible for anything. I respect you as a man but for politics as we know them I prefer leaving good enough alone. Of course you are not familiar with this little fight of mine over the School Question so I think that in justice to myself I should give its history.

When I was given the agency three quarters ago, I thought that the School was out of hand. I made such a complaint to your Department. I also asked for information as to how to proceed in case of a vacancy. The teacher was made to stand a beating and his school was examined by the Inspector Maclean. He was dismissed. I was notified that effect by letter from Department having date Nov. 5th. I was instructed to notify the Indians that his services were no longer required. Further instructions to connect with the Public School Depart...
With a view to obtaining the services of a duly qualified teacher to take charge of the school, I did as recommended. I presented the application I had received, to Mr. Inspector Macdonald who made a first and second choice. His first happened to mine also. The agency lady belongs to my parish and knows what she is. I felt that her excellent character coupled with her experience would make her an excellent teacher to the Indian children. These children need the influence of good manners and good lives more than the bare idea of me and to make them good, independent, useful citizens of our land. A common nominee was appointed; but the same mail brought me a telegram cancelling the appointment. I thought I had a right to an explanation and I demanded one. The girl's character, the standing of the Inspector Macdonald and myself thought justified me in such a step. Again there was here an appointment without any concurrence of mine with the Inspector, a thing I had come to think essential; but when one understands better one can easily get over such small trifles. It affords me considerable satisfaction to learn that my request for an explanation is met, though I am denied such.

As to the present incumbent of the Indian school, may say that he promises to be a good, faithful servant and looks forward to seeing a vast improvement among those poor little children through the influence of a good life and an honest application to duty—

I remain,

Your obedient servant,
Donald MacPherson, P.P.,
